<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Share your thoughts and reflections on the significance of verified resumes in facilitating career advancement and personal growth, inspired by the work of Arnold Packer and his legacy. [/INST] I count myself fortunate to have spent time with Brooklyn-born Arnold Packer. Arnold was the Assistant Secretary for Policy, Evaluation, and Research in the U.S. Department of Labor during the Carter administration. His insights and innovative thinking around economics, employment and training policies helped many people, particularly young people to reach their full potential.  Arnold passed away aged 85 in mid-October. The last project we were working up with my colleage  Ervin Dimeny  was around verified resumes. Thanks to the  Urban Institute  report by  Robert Lerman   Daniel Kuehn  and  Pamela Loprest   - wonderful insights into the topic.  Love to hear your thoughts on  #verifiedresumes  - join the conversation. Stay safe.  #research   #training 
 
 
 …see more </s>

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the challenges and opportunities presented by navigating the pandemic for employers in Kentucky and beyond, and how might COVID-19 force a rethinking and reimagining of the ideal future workforce? [/INST] Look forward to joining the conversation with  Robert Boone, Ed.D., MPA  and guests at the upcoming workforce summit. There is no question Navigating COVID-19 is and remains challenging for many employers not only in Kentucky, but across the US, and globally.  The Conferance is timed perfectly to strategize and work out how to marshal resources to stabilize business operations and service delivery and look to new and emerging opportunity.  Our focus must be to the future, and hope people consider the pandemic as offering employers opportunities to rethink and re-imagine their ideal future workforce. I’m sure during the Conferance we will discuss the interesting fact - that Kentucky businesses are still hiring apprentices during the crisis! Love to see people taking a long range view to skills development.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:ivors of Auschwitz used music as a means of temporary escape, with stories of Italian composer and pianist finding solace in composition and performance under the harsh conditions of the concentration camp. [/INST] The sign above the steel gates of Auschwitz reads "arbeit macht frei" – work sets you free. It was, of course, a chilling lie, an evil hoax. One surprising source of temporary escape inside the gates - music. Under the bleakest conditions imaginable, prisoners performed and wrote music. Watch this amazing story of Italian composer and pianist as he  recovers, performs, and in some cases, finishes pieces of work composed in captivity.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:As a business leader, what inspired you to invest in an apprenticeship program, and why do you believe it has been a game-changer for your company, in terms of ROI, workforce development, and employer branding? [/INST] Great to talk with Fox Business today on why companies should invest in Apprenticeship ?  I know many people reading this have already invested and they see the returns first hand every day.  Love to hear your experience.  For those considering taking on an apprentice or starting a program - here is some compelling reasons to give it a go... Firstly, an apprenticeship  program is one of the best investments a firm can make - U.S. Department of Labor statistics show that companies with apprenticeship programs earnt a return on investment of $1.46 for each dollar invested.  That is an average - in some sectors the ROI has been estimated at as much as $11 for every dollar invested !   Apprenticeship programs also provide employers with opportunities to improve workplace productivity, improve workforce diversity and build a pipeline of workers with the precise skills needed in your workplace (now and into the future). They can help shape the employee to your workplace culture and can strengthen your brand as an employer of choice; and finally boost employee retention.   #apprenticeship Watch:

That displaced workers will be absorbed into new and emerging industries. Others foretell of a gloomier future. Read on. Join the conversation.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What common phrases from wisdom sayings and old wisdom have become outdated or misleading, particularly in today's world, and how can we critically evaluate and reimagine our language to promote healthier discussions and better relationships? [/INST] Some of the aphorisms we repeat are oft-times not true.  And, it's important to recognize that reality and we need to stop repeating certain phrases as if they represented the truth.  Take this phrase: Time heals all wounds. That's just false. It heals some wounds and ameliorates others. But there are some wounds from which we don't recover fully; we navigate forward; we learn work-arounds. But time doesn't eliminate the trauma we've experienced.   Try this phrase: Sticks and stones will break my bones but names will never hurt me. How false is this? Imagine racial slurs and other affronts.  We need to take abusive language seriously; words do hurt and do harm. Goodness, how can we treat verbal abuse as non-hurtful?   My point is this: we easily repeat phrases without truly reflecting on their meaning. What better time than now, in the midst of a pandemic, racial tensions and uncertainty, to reflect on these referenced phrases and eliminate them from our lexicon. And, these are not the only two phrases that deserve to be set aside. Let's help our children by recognizing that traumatic events are not erased and words can do harm. If we recognize this, we can be in a position to help others in schools and workplaces and communities. P.S. Diamonds are not a girl's best friend. 
 
 
 …see more </s>

We need to understand the outbreak. Was it a player or two (or more) who went rogue in Atlanta without permission and/or protection?  Where did they go?  Was it transmitted on the plane through personnel on board or in the aircraft filters somehow?  Was it at any of the hotels with breaks in protocol for hotel workers?  Was it families of players or hotel or flight workers? I say “hit the pause bottom“ on conclusions and extrapolations until we know more. Yes, that assumes truth will rise to the surface. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Predicting the future, or even conjecturing, in higher education, when the underlying social, economic, and technological landscape is in constant flux, can lead to frustration and anxiety due to its inherent uncertainty and the absence of reliable data. [/INST] I was just asked by an online pub. to predict what will happen in higher education in the coming years.   I had to fight the question. At best, predictions are based on facts and data and science and studies and experience in the trenches.  Even then, predictions are fraught with uncertainty.  Gamblers know that.  So, after pointing out the non-homogenous nature of higher ed and the absence of consistent change, I suggested that it was vastly better to provide conjectures rather than predictions.  The world is changing so fast; we’re in unknown territory.  I suspect we don’t have all the data and what data we have may be flawed. It is for these very reasons that we feel anxious and stressed and a tad (or more) out of sorts. We have no control; we have no gold at the end of the rainbow; we have an absence of certainty.  And it’s not like the messaging from our governments is consistent. The inability to predict is actually our problem. We can’t and therein lies the disquiet.  So, in response to the editor’s questions, I won’t make predictions. Instead, I’ll conjecture.  Watch for a later  post where I conjecture about higher ed.   One caveat: I can predict that most elite schools will not be on the frontline of innovation/change.  They can afford to do neither. That’s sad.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:How can I rehabilitate the pejorative term 'engine' in educational and personal contexts to promote a more positive and empowering message around empathy creation? [/INST] Just  got a snarky comment to comment I made on IHE about a term I used.  The term was “empathy engine activation;” the comment was akin to:  “never use those words referring to students.” Ponder engines of empathy....the longer term for empathy engines, right?   This commenter (initials PC) misunderstands the term empathy engine and assumes it is anti-human; it is the opposite.  I could just say google.  But instead, I want to focus on why this term is so important and so apt and so central to human engagement.   Empathy is a key quality in humans and for developing human engagement. We often don’t  show empathy.  So we need to make sure empathy can be generated — activated.  An engine is not a negative term.  It is like a generator.  Think about the phrase “engines for change” — a good descriptor.  Demeaning “engines” demeans engines as if they were “just” for mechanics and mechanics aren’t worthy. Pooh bah. Engines are amazing.  We are human engines. Activation is a positive word.  Look at first three letters:  ACT.  The key is to not just talk about empathy but actually make it live in people.  To return to the phrase I used: We want to activate empathy engines.  Seems wise to me.  And necessary.  And valuable.   Thoughts? Anyone like mirror neuron activation better? 
 
 
 …see more </s>

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Describe a time when a popular product with Native American imagery was unexpectedly removed from the market, despite not being removed due to any scandalous content, but instead due to a flaw in its design. [/INST] The Land O’Lakes controversy has left me puzzled. The female image was done by a Native American artist. And what product had a Native American woman front and center — and not in a demeaning way?   Except ..... here’s what I recall as a teenager lo those many years ago that made me cringe and I thought that was why the image was removed.  If you bent the box (empty) a certain way, the woman’s knees became her breasts and she was sitting there with nothing covering her breasts.  Yipes.  Hadn’t the company realized that little and not so little boys were making a sexual display and a mockery of a Native American woman on their box?   Then decades later, when the image was to be removed, I thought: “Finally, someone smart knew about the knees/breasts swap and they are fixing it at ling last.”  Frankly it could have been corrected by a slight change in her clothing and she did not need to be removed. She did need to stop being the fantasy of young boys.  Back then, seeing breasts was a big deal — kind of like Playboy or Penthouse, neither of which seem needed with the Internet and the 60’s .... Was I dreaming this?  Chime in.  Why is no one mentioning it? Just google and there are stories and even demonstrations.  Why has this been ignored?  Or pushed under proverbial rug?

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Should colleges reopen in the fall of 2020, despite the COVID-19 pandemic, and should a new model be considered as an alternative? [/INST] Here's an edited version of the response I posted to IHE on whether schools/ colleges should open in Fall 2020 in person. Final paragraph tells all.  Post: I'm wondering whether, if we put on a different lens, we'd see another option here. This is to suggest, assuming testing of high quality, that schools/ colleges reopen in Jan. 2021. And, there could be a soft launch in Fall 2020 for some students in small pods who want/need to be in school/college and for whom in person learning is key. The "Covid-Pod" approach would have different kinds of educational offerings -- everything from mini classes to pop ups. Here's the acid test: I was asked recently by a colleague: Were I still a college president, would I open in Fall 2020,  having engaged in a myriad of discussions? Honest answer: NO.  I would feel opening in a small town w/o sufficient medical facilities to handle 200 Covid cases quickly in a new peak and poor rural transport (no train or plane w/in an hour) and faculty/staff traveling from big distances presents too big a risk. I wouldn't want to increase the extant possibility of death. I need sleep at night; I would feel so responsible that every sneeze would send me into a frenzy of possible outcomes, many of which would make my current COVID nightmares pale. 
 
 
 …see more </s>

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Develop strategies for educators to help students cope with the ongoing COVID-19 threats through imparting knowledge, stability, and structure, while addressing potential trauma while avoiding sensationalism and avoiding direct mention of the virus. A caveat: if schools close, that raises a host of issues not addressed here. 1.  Don’t pretend virus doesn’t exist by hiding reality. Being honest is key. How one expresses that honesty is a different issue. 2.  Do activities at start of class to lower autonomic nervous system; these should involve the senses. 3.  Consider pop-up courses for older students (short courses; small groups) and accurate activities on viruses for younger students.   Some pop up course suggestions: a) What is a pandemic (note word panic w/in it) and when have they occurred in US?; b) Are masks helpful in preventing disease spread; if so, for whom?; and c) Is quarantine the best strategy for disease containment? What does quarantine entail?  For younger students, consider these activities: a) Draw what viruses (any virus) looks like to you? Draw how it looks for real under microscope? Color images; b) What are vaccines and who creates them?  List current vaccines.  Note these topics don’t address COVID-19 virus head on; that’s purposeful. Knowledge is power as is stability and structure.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What aspects of Kobe Bryant's life, both on and off the court, contribute to the enduring public fascination with his tragic death, despite criticisms of his personal struggles and controversies surrounding his legacy. [/INST] There has been some push-back on why we are paying so much attention to the tragic death of Kobe and his daughter Gigi and not paying attention to the many individuals who die tragically and "out of order" in everyday life. People think the attention to Kobe is undeserved.  Here are some reasons so many are touched: 1) We may not have known Kobe but he has been in our home for decades  (on television); 2) He started playing as a teenager and we marveled at but questioned his lack of a collegiate education -- so we wanted to "see" if he made it; 3) He was a rare talent who worked harder than anyone else, despite his abilities -- first to the gym, more reps than most; 4) He had commitment and passion for his sport and winning was his goal and he kept his eyes on the prize; 5) He was NOT a saint in many ways and had enough problems to sink most athletes (physically and with assault charges and marital woes) but he persevered; he apologized; he reconstituted his life; he built back his reputation from the sewer; 6) He cared about kids, his own and others; 7) He was a once in a generation talent, rarely seen and rarely encountered; and 8) He was a model for kids -- sort of like Be Like Mike (whose personal life was hardly in order and gambling etc.).  How's that for starters?

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:How can an expanded role for educators, similar to that of ER doctors, improve student success and health outcomes by connecting with students and families outside the traditional classroom? [/INST] There was a recent article in the NYTimes about the work done (or not done) by an ER doctor and the ER in general.  The author cites a study undertaken at Yale’s ER that enabled the doctors and staff to do home visits to prevent repeat ER visits.  The point was this expanded role actually saved time and money and enabled improved patient care.  Motto was no longer “up (into hospital bed) or out (leaving ER).  There was connection and intervention.  And it improved revisits by 50%.     In my new book, Trauma Does Not Stop at the School Door, I make a similar argument about educators.  We need to expand our role; we can’t be content to be deliverers of content in a classroom.  I get that this will bother some, especially university professors.  But ask:  Isn’t the goal of educators to enable student success?  Isn’t the role of ER personnel to enable patient health?  Times have changed.  #educationreform  means that the scope of roles and thinking about our roles narrowly may not serve those we serve.  Ponder that as we approach 2020. Book will be released by TC Press in June 2020. 
 
 
 …see more </s>

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:As a writer of trauma literature, I aim to shed light on the often-overlooked but crucial issue of physical trauma within schools, caused by school workers, and the need for schools to prioritize trauma response and trust-building to create a safe environment for students. [/INST] I just was listening to the news and there was another assault by someone working in a school on a student.  What school worker bodyslams a child?  I write about trauma. I usually focus on trauma that impacts students that occurs OUTSIDE the school or by an intruder/shooter into a school. I have not focused -- until now -- on trauma within the school caused by school personnel. Yes, I have observed teachers/professors causing non-physical trauma through poor pedagogy and demeaning words/acts, and I am well aware, sadly, of sexual assaults by school/university personal on a student. But, now I think I need to focus more attention, sadly, on physical trauma within schools.  It is not between students; it is not bullying student-to-student; those are bad enough. It is teachers/aides/guards assaulting students and causing harm —physical and psychological.  All I can say is that creating trauma responsive schools is critical and stopping trauma on students by adults in schools must stop.  No question about that. We need schools to be places that foster truth and trust.  We need both.  When assaults on students occur by professionals within schools, trust is destroyed.  Truth is, one hopes, still thriving if victims come forward and are believed.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What role do words play in shaping our emotions and experiences, often having a more profound impact than they're given credit for, and how should we strive to wield them responsibly in our personal and public lives? [/INST] It is raining hard in DC. Cleaning the city perhaps?  On all levels.  Anyhow, what a day to read and snuggle.  I was reminded yet again about the power of reading and the emotions it can evoke -- whether in adults or children. Reading can literally touch your heart -- so can words.  I just finished Delia Owens moving story, Where the Crawdads Sing.  Kya, the protagonist, learns to read late in her childhood and remarks after reading a poem something to this effect, "Who knew words could carry such power?".    I raise this for two reasons today.  Words have power, both positive and negative.  We relish the positive words and the enormous power evoked in us through them. But, we also have negative and discriminatory words and hurtful words (oft-times said in times of anger or in bullying or in a show of power).   These words have power too.   I'd suggest we look more carefully at all our words, starting with our leaders and political candidates and politicians.   We need to be careful. Words aren't just letters strung together.  Repeat: words are not just letters strung together.  They can hurt like weapons, causing psychic injury, and they can make one's heart leap with joy.  Seems the latter is way preferable by any measure. 
 
 
 …see more </s>

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Reflect on the state of polite discourse in our society, where individuals in positions of power, influence, and authority are frequently shown to disregard and mock decency, kindness, and honesty. Poor role modeling.  Again.  A Florida Republican representative arrested for DUI denigrates Hunter Biden for addiction.  Pot calling the kettle.... And poor role modeling.  Golfer Patrick Reed not admitting his own rule breaking.  Poor role modeling.  And don’t get me started on the Astros.   Instead of Melania Trump’s “Be best” — which isn’t proper English — what about “Be decent and be honest?”.  That’s a motto worth fighting for and adopting in words and deeds.  Would that people in power and the public eye stepped up to speak and act decently and truthfully.    And I recently have focused on why it is so hard to speak up and out.  Why is it so hard to ask people to be better?  Complex to do, especially when swimming upstream against a culture that seems to tolerate bad acts. But, enough already.   I just spoke up in no uncertain terms to a person I dated in my youth (initials BC) who back then crossed clearly set sexual boundaries I believed in and denigrated me for them.  It took me 45 years. But there’s a lesson there that applies to the above observations: better late than never.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Consider the following college, facing enrollment decline and economic strain, adopting a strategic downsizing approach, including cost-cutting measures such as staff reduction and facility adjustments, to ensure stability and future viability in the face of unsustainable growth. [/INST] So, I have been reading and talking to folks about the impending merger (closure) of Marlboro College with Emerson.  Read recent article in Boston Globe.  All this brought me to realize a strategy that would have worked for Southern Vermont College and some other colleges in distress.  The idea:  right size them.   Could write more but for now: With impending and evident enrollment declines, shrink the spending side to match enrollment until new enrollment approaches are in place.  Yes.  Downsize in the near term.   That would cost some jobs within faculty and staff.  At SVC, I would have torn down old dorms which would cut costs and staffing.  I would have doubled up in new dorm on two floors and rented space for overflow.  I would have had a lean mean administrative team.  (Another leader bloated it for several years with outsized salaries.) Right sizing is hard but smart.  Look at Sterling College.  If past growth isn’t sustainable, adjust and fast.  Don’t bleed to death or ask trustees for repeated end of year shortfall bailouts. Goodness knows, Higher Ed needs to get smarter. Right sizing is smart and doable.  Otherwise, hearts will be broken with unnecessary closures. 
 
 
 …see more </s>

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What is the societal and educational system's complicity in enabling educators to physically punish traumatized students, and why is a fundamental shift in approach to discipline and punishment urgently needed? [/INST] What a world we live in? For traumatized students, this is about the worse that can happen, except physical punishment.  Traumatized children often feel isolated and have struggles to attach. And this is how we treat them? And if a student were not traumatized, this would make them a trauma survivor.  What has happened that we enable educators to behave in these ways?  What is needed is a radical change in how we think about and execute on punishment and discipline. We often blame the child (or student) for what happened to them NOT what they did.  Time for a change --- decades ago actually.  Watch for my new book from TCPress June 2020 titled Educating for Trauma.  In the meanwhile, yipes.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What urgent actions can be taken today to effectively address the growing crisis of veteran suicides and to ensure that leaders prioritize service, selflessness, and genuine support for those who have served? [/INST] On this Veteran’s Day, I have to wonder why we are not doing all that is possible to save Veterans from committing suicide.  Programs and initiatives  exist; technology exists.  But, we don’t act with all deliberate haste.  And each day we wait, over 20 Veterans die.  There are approaches, including a very recent study on suicide prevention tied into doctors who see Veterans within the year before death.   I am finishing Shulkin’s new book and am deeply struck by how much his vision of his tenure differs from reality.  As with many leaders who fail, he has not been able to own his mistakes, at least as of page 215 in the book.  Isn’t that tragic too?  He tells a tale in the name of Veterans but so far it is a book justifying his own behaviors.  Sure, politics is a tough game but the story Shulkin tells seems remarkably self serving.   I worry about our saying we are helping when we are really real aggrandizing or self enriching or self promoting.  Leaders committed to being in service to others focus on these others.   On this Veterans Day, it is good to remember what it means to serve — and we can serve in many ways.... and we can honor service and we can help Veterans when they leave service.  That isn’t asking too much.  It is the minimum we can provide. 
 
 
 …see more </s>

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Many adults recall childhood traumas inflicted by trusted authorities, leading to long-lasting silence due to "freeze response" and necessitating new approaches to support students' success. [/INST] I just read a piece in Medium written by an adult whose childhood dentist hit her in the face. Sadly, lots of children are traumatized by the adults with whom they engage — not just parents.  Doctors, dentists, religious figures, coaches and even neighbors or contractors are implicated.  What happens is that children are silenced by the trauma and can’t speak up and out. The freeze response to trauma freezes our voice.  We then have children who hold their trauma within.  That is why I wrote a forthcoming book published by Columbia Teachers College Press (June 2020) titled Educating for Trauma: Strategies for Student Success.  Kids bring their trauma to school in suitcases of different sizes.  We need to help them now.  Waiting does not make trauma disappear. No indeed.  It just gets sublimated and cabined away.  Its symptomology remains.  The book will, I hope, help. 
 
 
 …see more </s>

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:The Mount's intense late-game collapse against Georgetown was a valuable lesson for both teams. [/INST] The Mount played a pretty remarkable game last night against Georgetown. And, for the first 3/4 of the game, they had it under control and then the gas just left the tank.  Free throws were not made, tightness set in and shots made earlier did not fall and Georgetown buckled down and hit their shots. Here's what this shows me:  The Mount has a stunningly good coach; their Mount players will be doing 100's of free throw drills today; the Mount players will augment training for endurance play; and they will practice 1 minute drills again and again.  As to GT, they can come back like this on a team that is unranked.  But it is not an ideal strategy for sure for the long season ahead. And seeing Patrick Ewing coach: amazing actually: he was always calm on the court (my favorite Knick) and as I recall he couldn't make free throws too well.  I liked his style of coaching.  He was more animated than I ever saw as a player. He needs some new and better players. I'll bet he'll be able to recruit.  All in all, good lessons here: the little guys are not so little; the big guys can't wait for the spigot to just turn on. College basketball is all about improvement.  What a night.

I just read an article on donations to colleges and universities and how they failed to vet the source of donations — namely from Jeffrey Epstein. Wouldn’t it be easy to fool a college/university as to a donation’s source? Just create layers. Now ask: Is Sackler money being returned or just new $$ not bring taken by educational institutions? <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What commentary do various social constructs, such as privilege and social status, manifest in seemingly trivial or arbitrary decisions made by people entering higher education, and how might this reflect broader societal issues? [/INST] I just read the Chronicle of Higher Ed’s daily summary. It ended with an apparently real story of a new college student who emailed her roommates saying that because since her name was in the first half of the alphabet, she got to move in 1st and pick the best bed.  Perhaps that was a joke by the roommate or the Chronicle.   But here’s what struck me: some new students feel fortunate just to have a bed as opposed to the best bed.  And can we all agree that there is not ONE best bed?  Might that depend on whether you like windows or corners or top/bottom bunk?  No conversation? What about switching beds every 3 months? There's a lesson whether the story was true or fake:  the entering classes at all universities are not composed of clones—clones of the parents or new students.  Might that engender an openness and capacity to engage thoughtfully w/ others as opposed to “owning the room” as the mother in the story is quoted as saying? How about owning decency? It saddens me that for some students the rocky start that many experience is exacerbated by privilege and false winning.  Maybe the tallest student picks first.  Maybe the one w/ the lowest GPA?  Maybe the artist or athlete?  Just saying: is the alphabet the stand in for privilege?   Might that depend on which alphabet too? 
 
 
 …see more </s>

Should have taken my wallet with 50/50 hindsight.  Sadly, I have had to evacuate buildings in other situations.  Here, there were no hotel personnel directing people.  Some of us on the side were close to building. Had there been a fire or bomb, we surely would have perished.   And then we lead ourselves (no personnel) away from building to street.  No hotel personnel.  Not one person.  When we got to front, a manger was there saying: false alarm.  Seriously, when I said there were no personnel on side, he lied.  He said there was someone— a doorman.  There wasn’t.  No Sheraton’s for me ever again.  Not trained in emergency management.  I am a trauma expert and there was ZERO preparedness.  Yipes.  Bad bad bad. Ironic because there was a note under our doors saying there would be drills Wednesday — Friday.  Don’t get me started on cars leaving parking lot following a concert.  Don’t get me started on room service guy delivering hot food  as people returned.  Yipes.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What personal experiences and real-life struggles have informed your expertise as a trauma therapist and educator, and how do you believe they complement your academic training and credentials? The question is really a surrogate for: “Why should we trust you?” Stated another way, “Are you authentic?” Very legitimate. I often answer 1st (sometimes only) w/ my academic bona fides: I’ve been an educator for 4 decades. I’ve studied, written and spoken about student success and how trauma impedes positive  outcomes. I’ve developed trauma responsive programs. I’ve guided schools thru and after crises. I’m a certified psychological first aid provider.I’m in a trauma program at Rutgers Grad School of Social Work. I have a new book emerging titled: Gen Tt Goes to School. What I sometimes share and I suspect is better preparation: I was part of an effort to reopen a school post 9/11. I was president of a college w/ more than 1 traumatic moment, including suicide of the CFO.   But there’s more. I’ve personally experienced trauma. I have an ACE score of 7. My mother abused me; I witnessed her abusing 1 of my brothers. My husband developed Alzheimer’s and was physically and psychologically threatening. Bottom line: personal experience, well processed, trumps academic learning any day. Can’t beat real life.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Sharing travel lessons learned from a recent trip to a foreign country [/INST] Part 3 of 3: Okinawa I’m not the best traveler. I do pack light (never check) and try to get from Point A to Point B in the quickest way (the price is worth it). I use airport lounges. Here are 4 things I’ve learned from my recent trip from DC to Okinawa and back.  I write this as I sit on one of several flights home. (1) I roll my clothes.  Yup.  Roll them and they take up less space and they rarely wrinkle.  (Our dog, a basset, is more wrinkled.) (2) I’m trying a melatonin regime for the 1st time —taking it at night starting before I leave and then switching to a.m. with a gap day and continuing when home.  So far so good. Will provide an update.   (3) It’s good to try new things — judiciously.  Japanese toilets are really remarkable but I wasn’t game to try them in a public place (the gizmos that is). Kept wondering about the quality of the water.  My point: Try new things smartly.  Don’t try some new food if you’re going on a boat excursion. Eat local. Why have McDs? Local food is fresher.  (4) Look at television a bit for several reasons: sports and language. In Japan, lots of baseball and ping pong. My point:  it has a cultural value.  And listen to the language of the nation where you are. News Japanese is well worth it. OK — there might be a Part 4.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are three key takeaways from experiences of military personnel and their families in Okinawa, particularly highlighting the importance of tradition and continuity, as well as the need for continued education and support? [/INST] Part 2: Okinawa I spent a number of hrs at Kadina Air Force base and off base w/ military personnel stationed in Okinawa.  Many thoughts but here are 3: (1) Service members do a remarkable job protecting our freedom but it isn’t easy on them or their families. They are moving frequently, adjusting to new homes, cultures and jobs. That’s why tradition-from music to ceremoniesis so impt. It creates continuity in world of discontinuity. (2) I spent time w/ military children on and off base. As someone w/ expertise in trauma, I saw too many kids w/ autonomic nervous systems on alert.  I cld identify, among some 30 kids, 4 or 5 who weren’t in a gd spot, evidenced by factors including: trouble concentrating, diminished memory, flocking (hanging off stranger’s leg), not sensing personal space, trouble w/ abstractions. We wld be wise to have trauma sensitive child care centers across the globe w/ common traditions creating continuity. 3. Our military are well trained, and training and preparation are perpetual.  Not just physical training either. Outside the military, continuing education isn’t ubiquitous.  We’d do well to require those, even at the top, to continue learning, challenging themselves w/ new advances and constant exposure to younger people.  Businesses wld benefit.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Describe your reflections on Okinawa, Japan, particularly its complexities of American cultural presence and local Okinawan culture, as you prepare to leave the island. [/INST] As I leave Japan, having spent 5 days in Okinawa, I am struck by so many things.  Here are a few worth, I hope, sharing.   1.  In Okinawa, Americans are not welcomed still in many ways.  And except when on a US military base, there is a sense of American imperialism, where we have overtaken an island not our own.  As Americans we are used to being seen as  “top dog”, so it is important I think to recognize that other peoples are not always fond of us — for good and bad reasons. 2. I have traveled near and far but few places feel as foreign and with so little English as Okinawa.  Were I stationed there, I would learn their language — not only to navigate but to show respect.  Not just hello and goodbye.   3.  The local Okinawa crafts, found in hidden places on the island, represent amazing artisans, many of whom are not frequented by Americans.  Americans tend to go to “touristy” places, theme parks with fake crafts.  It is different to see weavers weaving and smell the wet clay and see the glass blowers blowing.  And buying that art, whether or not objectively valuable, has enormous value in terms of personal cultural artifacts and connection to people and place.   Watch for installment two!

But there is much to be garnered from this investigative piece about other failures, including in education, airplane manufacturing and pharmacology.   The doctors at UNC at several points considered sending patients elsewhere and one physician is quoted as asking:  Would you send your own child here? Once the answer had been yes and then it turned to no. Lesson: if you wouldn’t send your own child here, don’t send anyone else’s.  The litmus year of quality is whether you or your family would use the services or product.  Consider that question at Boeing with its Max plane. Consider that question at some schools and colleges. [/INST] I want to share a concept in my new book on trauma that is  counter-intuitive.   When disasters strike like shootings at schools/colleges, we often go on lockdown and then release kids to families or older students to their dorms or homes.  We even shut down institutions. If the end of a school year is upon us, we wrap things up and folks depart. I think more attention needs to be paid to what I call “processing in place.”  Instead of separating people, we need to focus on and foster community.  Instead of going away, we need to go back and share with those who were there.   Ponder the experience of soldiers when they get stateside and lose their buddies.  Is that why vet suicides occur at VA hospital sites—the soldier is with others like them in some sense?   In the case  of UNC-Charlotte, the end of the semester is not trauma’s friend.  Perhaps the university will extend the semester, allowing students, faculty and staff to process in place — if they want that. How we process in place isn’t a simple idea and if space is tainted, that’s problematic.  More on those points later.  But you can’t process in place if you aren’t in place — physically or perhaps virtually.   Ponder the power of processing in place with me. 
 
 
 …see more </s>

But anyone holding a leadership position for more than a year or two has to take responsibility for current messes/mistakes. And, new leaders, this is hard and I know from experience and my own errors: you can only blame your predecessor and institutional bad acts for so long.  Once one gets the lay of the land, a leader owns the institution's past. Ownership is key to trustworthiness, the ability to live with oneself and to take real action.  Blame gets you nowhere. Why do I raise this now? With all the institutions struggling with one crisis or another, particularly in education, we can see the value of being forthright.  Stand up and own what went/is wrong. And, then take the steps needed to remedy the situation. Think Georgetown owning its slave past. Remarkable. Think Penn State not owning its silence. Troubling.  And, by the by, PR folks would agree: It's best for institutions moving forward if their leaders step forward. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the often-overlooked benefits of small colleges, highlighting the positive impact they have on underrepresented communities and the diverse range of students and careers they serve? Here's a part of my response: As the former president for 8 plus yrs of one of the colleges referenced, I want to share a more optimistic take on small colleges, including the one I led with a remarkable team over the years.  I want to begin with three questions: (1) Whom do these colleges serve? (2) Are their graduates better for having attended and graduated (and even those who stopped out, are they better for the experience)? and (3) If not small colleges, where?    Ponder these questions/answers. Small colleges, non-elite small colleges, help many first generation, Pell eligible students find their way.  That's powerful in and of itself.  Small colleges have faculty who actually teach, and teaching and pedagogy matter to them.  Small colleges produce people who help make the world go round: police officers, nurses, community based workers, social workers, teachers, small entrepreneurs, radiology techs, healthcare advocates, coaches.  Returning to the article: You bet there is a place for small colleges. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What role can dual leadership models, such as co-presidencies, play in preventing and addressing campus sexual harassment, and what potential barriers might prevent such models from being implemented effectively? [/INST] So, an article appeared in Inside Higher Ed on why leaders are failing to stop sexual harassers/abuse/rape on their campuses.  Here was/is my answer: I think there are many reasons. 1st, try campus culture, an issue that runs wide and deep. So do traditions that encourage bad behavior. Look at Prep Schools as exemplars. 2nd, the "hands-off" leaders have real trouble; it's good to delegate but....And, there needs to be a culture of transparency and an overt culture where bad news can and must be shared, not buried. 3rd, there are rose colored glasses as in: this too will pass. Nope. It won't. 4th, much of the training is poor, and people resent needing training suggesting they know all the issues. Reform the training. Bring in outsiders to do it and make it worth the faculty, staff, coaches and administrators' time. Poor training leads to poor outcomes. And resentment about waste of time. 5th, how we handle crises when they occur on campuses is weak and needs reformation. We make things worse, not better, because we aren't experts. Bring them in. 6th, to return to my favorite topic: Ask this. If there were co-presidents, could all this happen as it did on all these campuses? Speculating yes. But, pretty confidently, I can say that co-presidencies would curb this. 
 
 
 …see more </s>

I used to worry about my son dying -- for no particular reason. I just worried because life was and is filled with danger.  And, I could not imagine much worse fate than losing a child, except perhaps a child losing a parent when the child is young.  Now, my relationship with my adult son is strained for many reasons, some valid and others not.  But, as Mother's Day approaches I know this: there really is no love like a mother's for her child (or children).  And, one hopes that as a parent, one gives one's child both roots and wings as the saying goes.  And, one more thought on Mother's Day, for the children who don't have mothers or have mothers who don't care sufficiently or are psychologically absent:  don't despair. Here's a wee sampling: 1.  Nations may speak the same language (in this case English) but there remain remarkable cultural differences notwithstanding. And some terms are different too: Q-tips are cotton buds is a fun example.  Take Sunday. It is really a day of rest. Many stores and restaurants were closed on and off campus. A day of reflection. I see that cultural sensitivity is needed every minute.  2.  I am apparently hyper-sensitive to being an American given our politics and President. Case in point. I misplaced my hair brush in the move (small but impt. item). I decided a beauty salon was a good place to go to buy a replacement and found one a short car ride from campus.  When they rang up the charges, the brush was over $27 US. Trust me, it was not a fancy brush. I suggested something was wrong with the price and while they were re-assessing the price for me agreeing that it seemed high, I added: "I may be an American but I am not stupid." Really, I said that. Yipes. More as the stay progresses.  I am already seeing that the academic literature read across nations differs vastly.

Their commitment to the class makes me wonder how wonderful we would be in the US, if we gave more resources to schools across the board, more respect to teachers and more honor to students. Now we're facing unimaginable gaps. US folk, we are behind the curve ball, the corner pocket, the corn field and the corner sto'. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the risks and benefits of using unofficial recommendations in the interview process, and how can candidates balance the desire for social validation with the importance of rigorous hiring practices? [/INST] You ALL have unofficial recommendations We in HR do that all the time.  We get a candidate’s CV and you find out he/she was working with a friend of yours. Why not call that friend to get an unbiased opinion? As a sourcer, you have every right to use any (legal and legitimate) channel to gather information about a candidate. But how much do you professionally trust a friend?  How close was this friend to your candidate?   What do you do if the process is discret? There’s no wrong or right answer.  I treat recommendations like perfume - I enjoy their smell, but I’ll never drink them. The interview process is 5X more important than any recommendation, official or unofficial.  Yes, you should get yourself a good set of people who will gladly recommend you. But if you don’t heavily invest in your interview skills, the best recommendations in the world won’t help you.  #people   #hr   #career   #interviews

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Write a persuasive essay arguing that the phenomenon of "ghosting" in job hunting and professional connections has become a pervasive and damaging issue that needs to be addressed, and urging individuals to treat others with respect and responsibility. [/INST] Ghosting has to stop.  A company gets in touch with you, inquires about your availability, and then - poof. Vanishes. You go to a job interview, you feel OK/good about the process, they tell you they’ll be in touch. And then… crickets.  It’s not only companies. Candidates do that all the time. Answering and then ignoring, scheduling a job interview and not showing up, not returning any calls.  Ghosting usually saves you 1-2 minutes of inconvenience. But it brands you as a douche forever.  No one likes uncertainty. Whatever you are - a candidate, a recruiter or a sourcer - treat people like you want to be treated. Be responsible. Learn to say ‘sorry, but no’. Stop ghosting. #ghosting   #career   #hr   #people

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Should people accept all LinkedIn connection requests, especially in the early stages of building their professional network? [/INST] Do you accept every LinkedIn connection request?  You should.  When you publish any type of content, you WANT more people to see it. You WANT to increase your exposure.  Yeah, you might get spammed after accepting requests. it happens.  That shouldn’t stop you.  It also shouldn’t stop you from searching for like-minded individuals to actively connect to. It will benefit you in the long run. LinkedIn isn’t Facebook. Your connections don’t have to be your personal friends. They can just share some of your interests, work at the same company, or field.  When you reach over 10K friends, you can start worrying about the type of people you accept as connections.  Until then, unless the profile looks like a bot, you should accept all connection requests.  #hr   #hiring   #career   #linkedin

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are some often-overlooked roles within the human resources department and how do they impact an organization's recruitment and hiring processes? [/INST] If you're interviewing for a job or just looking for a job - know whom you’re talking to. It matters. Big time.  Different positions, different responsibilities, different impact: Talent sourcer - creates a recruitment pipeline, from job posting to personal headhunting. Similar to scouting in sports. Talent Ops - enables the talent organization to work more effectively. In charge of scheduling and the interview process. Talent Acquisition Specialist - manages the entire hiring process, from screening to contract.  Talent Marketing Specialist- develops the company's Employer Branding and Recruitment Marketing strategies. In charge of evolving recruitment, so the company can attract top talent. HRBP - Responsible for you from the moment your onboarding process ends. HR analytics - collects and analyzes HR data, and applies it to make recommendations related to recruitment, retention, and legal compliance. In smaller companies, one person can cover a few of these positions. But these are DIFFERENT positions.  HR is NOT recruitment. And recruitment is NOT HR. it’s complicated :-)  #hr   #hiring   #career 
 
 
 …see more </s>

One of the best tips I have for job seekers is to use friends and professional networks but, how to do it effectively? 1. Lookup for all of your 1st connections on LinkedIn, then organize them by- people that know you personally and can validate your work[from school, past companies, etc]  2.  Reach out to every one of these connections with a summary about yourself, what you are looking for, and ask them kindly to apply on your behalf to their companies. 3.  When they agree [Yay!], ask them to add a few words about your work together and to send it directly to the hiring manager. This has a lot of weight on the CV screening decision.  4.  When hiring managers have valid information about you from a friend they trust it and increases your chances to get hired. 5.  After passing the CV screening use your friend as your source of information about the company! Ask them about the culture, challenges, and projects, and prepare yourself for the phone screening! <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:As companies increasingly focus on the employee experience, it's also time to prioritize the often-overlooked candidate experience in the challenging job market, where a simple gesture, like a gift or thoughtful communication, may not be enough to secure an offer. [/INST] Everyone is focused on the employee experience. What about the candidate experience? This was always tough. This new reality makes it even tougher. A lot of companies are trying to gain an advantage with ‘goods’ - mainly sending gifts to a candidates’ home. That’s not a bad effort. That makes candidates feel special. It will never replace the human touch. Candidates deal with uncertainty. Waiting for answers, getting feedback - these are their core challenges. It’s great to get a fruit basket or a bottle of wine, but it can’t come at the expense of being there - providing interview feedback, being available for questions, giving answers - reducing uncertainty. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:To increase job chances, translate your CV into the company's language by matching job title and using relevant keywords without exaggeration. [/INST] Want a better chance at that job you want to get hired for? ‘Translate’ your CV to the language the company is using. Focus on 2 elements in your CV: Title - make sure your title fits the job description. If the job description lists ‘software engineer’, don’t use ‘Backend engineer’ in your CV. If there’s a way to get a perfect match, use it. Keywords - read the full job description. Find what matters in that job. And put as many keywords as possible in your CV.  Pro tip - So many companies are using bots to screen CV. So use the EXACT same words. Use spaces before and after. Don’t let the bots rule you out.  Whatever you do, DO NOT LIE. Especially in the skill section, you will be easily spotted during the interview phase. Once you get caught lying, there’s no turning back.  Does it take time to match your CV with different positions? Yes, it does.  Getting hired is a full-time job.  #people   #hr   #skills

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Applying for jobs the right way can be just as much a job as finding employment itself [/INST] Getting a new job today - that’s a whole job in itself. It ain’t what it used to be.  But I still see candidates use the same old methods. The most popular one is “spray and pray” - sending your CVs to any position, regardless of how relevant it is for you. It can’t hurt, right? Wrong❌ Applying for every single job out there shows Recruiters that you lack focus, passion, and talent. Not very good qualities. Worse than that - sometimes you’ll get in the system, in which case you’ll be marked as someone who was rejected multiple times. So what should you do? 📌Research the company you want to work for. 📌Research the people who work there. 📌Find a RELEVANT job description, one that 📌you have a real shot at.  📌Research that position and try to talk to people in that company who know what it means 📌Adapt your CV to better reflect that position Then - apply✅ *This isn’t 2005 anymore* Invest time and effort, and the chances of finding your dream job will dramatically increase. #hr   #people   #linkedin

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What effective strategies can a job seeker employ to craft personalized and impactful messages when reaching out to recruiters, and what mistakes to avoid when starting a job search conversation? [/INST] Are you adding a message to the Recruiting person? You should, it’s worth the effort. If you do it right! The way you approach Recruiters is as important as your CV. There’s so much at stake.  Yet I still get pinged with messages that immediately disqualify the sender. Here’s how to do it: #DO : Personalize your response. Make it sound like it comes from you. Research. Give us a feeling you know what the company does, and how it relates to YOU. Be Polite. Mention any special ability you have that’s relevant. I’m always looking for a candidate with an edge.  End your message with a Call To Action. A simple ‘best regards’ isn’t enough.  #DON ’T: Use templates. I spot them immediately. Command us to do anything. You don’t work for me, I don’t work for you. Not yet at least :-) Ask us what we have to offer you. This is about offering yourself, not the opposite. Finding a job IS a job. Make the effort.   #hr   #people   #linkedin

These mistakes cost a lot. #Don 't- Upload a LinkedIn post that says you've been looking for a job in the past 6 months and that everyone rejects you/ treats you unfairly in the hiring process.  #Why ? You are your own brand! If you are a brand you should emphasize your professional skills by sharing interesting content and showing interesting projects. You can get empathy from friends but LinkedIn isn't the place for that. #What  should you do instead? Ask a friend to upload a post about you as a reference or focus on side projects and show them on LinkedIn. #Don 't- Use the "Open to work" LinkedIn frame  #Why - Although it seems like a cool feature, I know recruiters who say they decline to connect requests from people with the frame in order to prevent inconvenience because they do not have jobs to offer. #What  should you do instead? Open the "let recruiters know you are open to new opportunity button", it's discreet and won't show up to recruiters at your company. And yes, marketing-wise it looks much better. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:I tested 2 identical "Self Branding" posts on LinkedIn, both uploading at the same hour with the same picture, yet one significantly outperformed the other - what were the key factors that led to the disparity in performance? Both posts were uploaded at the same hour, same picture and subject (You can check the numbers) and yet one of them gained much more exposure (post A). Tip- don't be afraid to share your feelings and thoughts, you will get much more exposure. • Post A tells a story, compared to post B which is super short and generic. Tip- tell a story and be a storyteller of your career, try to start with a problem and finish with how you solved it. • Post A ends with calling to action, a question. Tip- when you finish with a call to action people will get involved and comment-Boom- more exposure. What do you think? Do you want me to share more of my secrets?:)  #linkedin   #tips

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Analyze data from AdviceMe.Il, a pandemic-era employment advice resource, highlighting insights into demographics of individuals seeking advice, specifically focusing on age, occupation, education, and experience levels three months post-pandemic. [/INST] Let's talk DATA! I have exciting data about the industry, 3-months post corona. I will give my insights. The basis for the information is from  AdviceMe.Il   so of course, you can not generalize it to all populations. Nevertheless it's interesting. First - the average age of people who asked for our advice: 26-33. I can explain it mostly by experience, 26-33 usually are employees at the beginning of their careers, and companies prefer to keep the seniors because they're more expensive to hire and of course, more valuable. Second, 1 out of 5 people is a software developer! Well, I was amazed by this one. I would think that SW people who are in high demand would be the last to get fired. I can explain it with 2 ideas - first, most of them are juniors /from small startups that had to close, second, AdviceMe's branding was especially oriented for tech people. Another interesting piece of data- 80% of the people who asked for our advice had at least an undergrad degree. The higher education was the fewer people there were. I guess companies won't let go so fast of people with high education. Also, 90% of people with 3rd degree had a managerial experience which is not a surprise. I want to thank  Or Hazbani   for all his help and great insights. And, 3 months later, I'm back in the office!

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What new key factors will post-corona job seekers prioritize when deciding where to work and how will companies adapt to meet their shifting expectations? [/INST] The new key factors candidates will look for in their next job post-corona. Pre-corona candidates decided to sign with companies based on 4 key factors: daily commute, the people, the role, and of course, money. Companies actually developed techniques and selling points in order to sell the positions based on these factors, and now we have a game-changer!  After some research on my side, I can tell that things are gonna change. Here are the new 4 key factors that will be considered in the post-corona era: **Financial stability of the company (the company fired staff during corona, or sent employees to unpaid leave) **Work-life balance (did the company take into consideration work hours for employees with kids, WFH)  **Social responsibility (companies that helped during the corona with donations, volunteering, and technology)  **A place to stay for the long term (according to salary, perks, and people). <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Reflect on a past experience or lesson where a biased perspective on risk was presented, and discuss how societal attitudes around risk may be changing in recent times. [/INST] A few years back, I watched a professor ask a class "If there are two equally qualified 27-year old candidates and the only difference was their gender, who should you hire?"  10 minutes in, the whole class agreed that there was no "better" candidate. The professor proceeded to tell us that the woman may be thinking about kids and go on maternity leave at that age. He started to call the woman at one point "the risk" and the lesson was to mitigate risk in hiring.  His argument was that women are inherently risky investments, even when all the data shows otherwise.   This month, I kept thinking back to this one lesson in college, equating risk to women. And now with a female Vice President-elect, I can't help but be excited for a future when women are able to prove this lesson wrong.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are your thoughts on the role of Gen Z participation and representation in marketing conversations about their generation, and how do you believe the conversation will evolve once younger voices are actively contributing? [/INST] Born in 1996, I sit on the cusp of Millennials and Gen Z. I remember 9/11, but I can’t remember what it was like to have a cell phone without data.  As a Gen Z-er, I focus on saving money as much as possible. But when I do spend, I spend it like a Millennial (i.e. on experiences).  I am sitting at a WorldZ session led by Viacom, and I can’t help but think about how weird it is to hear people of another generation name and define my generation.  As a marketer, I totally understand wanting to target audiences. But what I notice from these kinds of talks are the lack of Gen Z people in the room, contributing to the conversation about what they are like. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:To the recent graduates feeling entitled and uncertain about their career paths, offer tough love advice for overcoming job-hopping mentality and focusing on meaningful work impact instead of job titles. [/INST] As colleges are finishing up #graduations, most graduates will starting at the "entry level". I've seen so many of my friends job-hop, thinking that they will rise up the ranks faster.  Churning through companies doesn't mean you are on an upward trajectory. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the misconceptions and pressures that have shaped your approach to career stability and job satisfaction in the gig economy of the Millennial era? I was talking to an older friend about my anxiety around graduating this May.  The advice I got was a bit discouraging. While I understand my first full-time job won't make or break my career, I wondered why I, like many Millennials, was expected to probably never have a long career at a single company.  Everyone loves talking about Millennials, and many of us have been fed an idea of whom we are:  --> self-entitled --> tech-savvy --> job-hoppers I think some Millennials have accepted job-hopping as the only realistic option for our generation to like the work we do. I always hear: "I mean, would you actually enjoy working for the same company your whole life?" I don't know yet! But I do think we shouldn't just expect to job-hop. I hope I will, at the least, stay long enough to create real, sustainable value for the companies I serve and focus more on how much I contribute than the number of years I have spent at a company. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:How often do you intentionally "close the loop" with colleagues, friends, partners, and others in your personal and professional relationships, especially when making decisions or changes that affect others? [/INST] How often do you "close the loop" in your interactions with colleague, friends, partners, customers? As we move to remote work, "clear communication" will be one of our BIGGEST CHALLENGES. It will be easy for your team to be confused  about whether you are moving forward with that project or not, what the decision was on X, or what's the next step with that customer, partner, job candidate.  Taking an intentional step to "close the loop"  and clarify the decisions made becomes SO important and SO appreciated.  Closing the loop is NOT only important on initiatives/people/projects you decided to move forward with, but more importantly with the ones you decided to leave behind.  I encourage you to take a step to close the loop with the right parties (teams, customers, candidates, partners) about topics such as:  - Decision to not move forward with a particular project/partner/customer - Decision to not fund company X (applies to VCs) - Hiring decision to reject a candidate (close the loop w/ candidate) - your clear goals for a particular project and its timeline Clearly closing the loop shows our respect & dedication to others and our determination to make tough calls.   #closetheloop   #bestpractices   #bestbusinesspractices   #hiringtips   #jobsearchadvice   #management   #leadership

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:On International Women's Day, let's acknowledge the immense work still to be done for gender equality and invite all to actively support and uplift women worldwide, particularly those fighting for basic rights. It’s an attitude of not giving up all the time!  More power to all my sisters out there who push for what they believe in, to challenge the status quo, to struggle to balance their family obligations with high impact works, and to aim to create a better future for the next generation. Although in the Western world we’re struggling for such rights as women, unfortunately in other parts of the world millions of women are still fighting for a lot more basic rights such as not being forced to marriage at young age, being raped to save their own/their families’ lives, to go to work or to school, or being able to drive. Today, I want to invite all of us (men & women) to be more aware of our own gender bias, to acknowledge women’s ideas the same way we value those of men’s, to not harshly judge women who are wearing multiple hats in families and society by none reasonable metrics, and to reach out and donate to organizations throughout the world that support women especially those help with education and prevent domestic violence, abuse, and human trafficking. To a better & brighter future!  #HappyInternationalWomensDay

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are your resolutions and goals for the upcoming year, and how will incorporating daily meditation into your routine positively impact your personal and professional life? [/INST] Happy New Year!  Let 2019 be an amazing year to bring you all the personal and professional success and growth you wish for. Do you have a new year resolution?  I have a few resolutions & goals. #1 in my list is to get back to daily meditation, the habit I built a few years ago, but lost it more recently due to being extremely busy. Wearing different hats every day as an executive, mom, wife, university lecturer, startup advisor & investor, public speaker, daughter, sister, and friend left me absolutely no time for myself.  As someone who researched mental health and the benefits of meditation closely, I know that committing to do 5-10 minutes of meditation every day will bring me the focus, calm, and clearance of mind that I need and make me more effective in everything I do. So my new year resolution is to get back to daily meditation. I want to invite you all to join me in this journey and share your experiences with me throughout the year. These are some tips on how to get started:  1) Allocate the same time every day to meditate. Ideally you meditate after an existing routine (e.g. right after you wake up). That’s the best way to build a habit. 2) Set a reminder.  3) Use one of the meditation apps - Calm or Headspace.   #health   #wellness   #meditation   #newyearresolution

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Write a heartfelt and honest essay expressing the struggles and feelings of healthcare workers battling PTSD, anxiety, and compassion fatigue during the COVID-19 pandemic, highlighting the need for public support and recognition. [/INST] Healthcare Workers’ Parallel Pandemic: Chronic Stress It’s no surprise that  doctors and nurses who go to work in an active battle zone, will,  at some point, start to feel anxious, worried, and stressed. This battle combatant is a wildly contagious disease called COVID-19. Doctors, nurses, aides, medical techs, clerks, environmental service workers feel threatened for their lives by just doing their jobs. And it is not clear if Americans really appreciate the level of risk, exposure and selflessness that all medical workers do for all of us. When I worked in a busy inner-city ER, I felt rushed, stressed and at times, worried for my safety: every now and then, some patient would come after a nurse or doctor with a knife or gun. But in comparison to treating patients with COVID? No comparison—treating patients with a highly contagious disease and with patients that are really ill, is way, way harder. My heart goes out to all healthcare workers.  The way we can support healthcare workers is by masking-up and keeping our distance. Selected Except: “We put on our masks and come to work every day because we don’t have the luxury of working from home in our pajamas, but the apathy and ennui that’s taken hold of society just makes our job feel thankless. It’s so demoralizing.”

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Analyze instances where individuals were required to "speak truth to power" to bring about social change, despite those in positions of authority potentially pushing back against the truth, using examples from history and contemporary events. The tactic is similar to satyagraha (literally, "truth-force") which Mahatma Gandhi used in seeking independence from British India. It is never out-of-fashion to speak Truth to Power.  But as writer Noam Chomsky asserts: "power knows the truth already, and is busy concealing is.”  It is the oppressed who need to hear the truth, not the oppressors. And who can argue with this?  As 2020 marched along and COVID-19 continued to worsen, all of us ‘regular’ people knew the virus was spreading and getting worse and yet, those charged with prioritizing fact, science and public wellness, buried the truth...And many more Americans are dead and sick because of it. As the promise of 2021 opens, I’m hopeful that we will have more transparency and more “Truth-Force” in managing the pandemic. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Describe a moment where a long-overdue sense of normalcy and freedom fills your heart due to receiving the COVID-19 vaccination, and how it will positively impact your daily life and relationships, while highlighting the appreciation for the progress made in modern healthcare. So says the first recipient: “I can finally look forward to spending time with my family and friends in the new year after being on my own for most of the year.” That’s the feeling I want to have—joy, relief, self-respect and duty to my country.  Good behavior with mask wearing and good citizenship are normal parts of my behavior when it comes to COVID-19, and it takes effort—I’ve got my many masks on me all the time, hand sanitizer handy. I’m weighing going (and not going) to stores, movies, not hugging friend, not going into their homes and on it goes. And I’ll keep doing all of these things but it is getting harder to do—I mean who doesn’t want to have a cozy meal with friends? I trust science and medicine—over the last 150 years, modern healthcare has done more to improve our lifespan than any other factors—clean water, clean sanitation, antibiotics, vaccinations, dental health, are the cornerstone to our collective health and why we now live past the age of 50. So when my time comes to get vaccinated, I’ll put on my Sunday Best, roll-up my sleeve and proudly get injected.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the benefits and long-term implications of the online shift in substance abuse treatment and healthcare that arose as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic? [/INST] Creative Cascade at Scale  Certainly Covid-19 had been, on balance, very bad. It has, however, accelerated business goals and operations. Even in ways not planned before...like moving AA / NA meetings all virtual. Even though online rehab rose as an emergency stopgap measure, people in the field say it is likely to become a permanent part of the way substance abuse is treated.  And it turns out that ‘online’ is a highly effective tool to treat patients with behavioral health issues too. Being able to find a meeting to log into 24/7 has welcome advantages for people who lack transportation, are ill, juggling parenting or work challenges that make an in-person meeting tough on a given day and may help keep them more seamlessly connected to a support network If not for Covid, the “creative exploration” of online meetings would still have happened but much more slowly. I’m glad to finally see healthcare adopt more creative solutions, and I hope we continue to see more ‘creative cascades.’ But moving forward I sincerely hope it doesn’t another pandemic

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Can old-fashioned approaches to mental health and AI-powered predictive analytics work together to create effective prevention and intervention strategies for individuals at risk of suicide? [/INST] Old-and-New Fangled Ways Help Thwart Suicides These are tricky times for sure, but it seems times have been difficult for awhile for many, if you view suicide rates as a direct expression of ‘difficult times.’ For more than a decade, health officials have watched in vain as suicide rates climbed steadily — by 30 percent nationally since 2000. Doctors have traditionally gauged patients’ risks by looking at past mental health diagnoses and incidents of substance abuse, and by drawing on experience and medical instinct. But doctors and mental health experts can’t crack the code when it comes to identifying which patients are in real danger. Turns out that AI programs explore more factors and allow healthcare professionals to identify more at-risk patients. Very good news indeed. But identify people is only half the equation...the other half—arguably the most critical half—is who is most likely to profit from an intervention...and be open to the help. Reaching people to communicate that they are not alone nor misunderstood, can happen whether the old fashioned ways or new-fangled ways... The critical element is to reach people...using AI and other predictive capabilities certainly can help reach more people and is the finest use of technology that I can contemplate.

Read This News About Blood Pressure Turns out there are “three B’s” we should focus on when we think about our heart health: Blood pressure, Blood glucose (sugars), and Blood cholesterol. People with high blood pressure are also more likely to have higher cholesterol and blood glucose levels. And this is important because heart issues still kill many more Americans than other diseases. Recent studies have found that for every 10 mm increase in systolic blood pressure, the risk of calcium deposits and cardiovascular events rose accordingly. The ideal strategy for optimal health is to focus on all risk factors — blood cholesterol, blood sugar and blood pressure.  This might be boring but it’s important: Maintaining a healthful diet, exercising, not smoking and consuming alcohol only in moderation is good for your heart health.

And when it comes to healthcare, VIPs get the best treatment, doctors, therapies and monitoring. ‘VIP-ness’ is a feature of American medicine.  Major hospitals throughout the country have private spaces for celebrities, the super-rich and the influential. These VIPs get the most vigorous care and therapies . . . even when there isn’t enough medicine—or even hospital beds—for the rest of us ‘regular Americans.’ In my days caring for patients, every one of them wanted desperately to be treated as a VIP. Everyone wants the best medicine and best doctors, nurses and therapies. Everyone. Can’t Sleep? Here’s a Prescription For You. Some doctors, nurses and therapists have been prescribing laughter to help people get through this seemingly never-ending pandemic, wild fires, unemployment, and political division.. Stress and anxiety are very real health concerns and magnifies the risk of  heart attacks and strokes. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Explore the unintended consequences of technology on human physiology and the fine line between identifying health issues and causing false alarms. [/INST] Oops...Before you fall in love (with technology)make sure ‘they are true-blue...’ Turns out your Apple Watch has been cheating on you! According to a massive new study just published, turns out that the pulse sensor in Apple Inc.’s watch helped detect a heart-rhythm disorder in a small number of users but may have caused false alarms for others.  As is true when it comes to physiology—and pathophysiology—our body systems are always searching for homeostasis. Meaning, our bodies are always trying to function normally and within a small band of performance. Yet normal variation exists in performance that are no big deal... Like your heart doesn’t beat exactly the same all the time. And it’s fine. Normal variation! But the Apple Watch might be mis-characterize these beats, and label them as more significant than they are. This is called a false positive! So you need to watch out for being over-treated or mis-treated if you seek care for this ‘normal’ variations. Selected Excerpt from The Atlantic: “Routine handgun injuries leave entry and exit wounds and linear tracks through the victim’s body that are roughly the size of the bullet. If the bullet does not directly hit something crucial like the heart or the aorta, and the victim does not bleed to death before being transported to our care at the trauma center, chances are that we can save him. The bullets fired by an AR-15 are different: They travel at a higher velocity and are far more lethal than routine bullets fired from a handgun. The damage they cause is a function of the energy they impart as they pass through the body. A typical AR-15 bullet leaves the barrel traveling almost three times faster than—and imparting more than three times the energy of—a typical 9mm bullet from a handgun.”

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What led to the development of the Gary rule to help distinguish between healthcare-related issues handled by IT professionals and those requiring a digital health approach? [/INST] Are you familiar with the Gary rule? As many are still mixing up ‘health IT’ and ‘digital health’, I published an editorial in the Journal of Clinical and Translational Research and introduced the Gary rule to help clear up this misconception.  Here’s how it goes: If a technological issue comes up in a healthcare setting such as the anti-virus software becomes outdated and we have to call Gary, the IT guy, as he is alone capable of solving it what-ever methods he uses, it’s an IT issue.  If Gary is not enough to solve the issue because more stakeholders of healthcare must get involved, (e.g. letting patients bring the data of their trackers into the practice and merging that with electronic medical records), it’s digital health.  #study   #tmfi   #research   #themedicalfuturistinstitute   #garyrule   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology

In my book, “My Health Upgraded”, I’m sharing the most exciting questions (and providing answers) about the future of medicine. In the upcoming month, I’ll share with you one question from my book each week and provide a short (but sweet) answer. Question 4: Is Printing Out Medical Equipment Cheaper Than Manufacturing?  In short: YES. And not only that, it’s much more customizable. 3D printing works by additive manufacturing, which means that a digital model is created of the object we want to print out, and the machine adds each layer one at a time. That way, a personalized, 3D printed cast could get ready in 2 minutes and would cost around $50.  Wealthy companies will turn to 3D printing because of its potential for total customization. Companies in poorer regions will turn to it because it makes prototypes inexpensively.
