<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:How can training AI algorithms to focus on predicting patient outcomes, rather than matching human performance, help address existing biases in medical technology and ultimately lead to improved healthcare? [/INST] Bias in A.I. might be the biggest challenge ahead in making A.I.-based technology truly useful for medical purposes.  But there’s a new paper in Nature Medicine that proposes to train algorithms to become better at predicting patient outcomes rather than to match the performance of their human counterparts. The paper presents this theory through a real-life example. Decades ago, a system was developed on white, British patients to determine their level of knee pain based on certain radiographic features of their X-ray.  This system systematically scores black patients far below the severity of pain that they self-report. When they trained a deep-learning model to predict the patient’s self-reported pain level from their knee X-ray without using data from the old system, they found that the model was much more accurate, especially for black patients, thereby reducing the racial disparity. Learn more about A.I. in healthcare to be able to understand, anticipate and control it. [/INST] I’ve just finished a book that casts light on one of the most remarkable features of our professional lives: the death of expertise. Experts need education, talent and the ability to communicate their talent, as well as peer appreciation. But all this is not enough anymore.  Now more than ever, people tend to question a doctor or a researcher simply because they claim to have read something contrary on the internet.  And since in a democracy everyone’s entitled to their own opinions, as an expert, you’re stuck with trying to transmit your knowledge and expert opinion. It has a truly crippling effect on informed debates on any number of issues. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are your hopes and concerns about the FDA's new AI action plan, particularly with regards to its potential impact on patient care, algorithmic accuracy, and regulatory framework? [/INST] The  FDA ’s new A.I. action plan just got published. Here are the main points: 1. Tailored Regulatory Framework My take: As the draft guidance about this with details will come out this year, I hope adaptive algorithms will be covered. 2. Good Machine Learning Practice My take: The FDA wants to harmonize such practices across a range of international organizations. I'm not sure it’s possible, since their detailed plan is still not ready. 3. Patient-Centered Approach My take: I would’ve expected the digital health arm of the FDA to appoint a patient engagement advisory board, as promoting a patient centric approach without actively involving patients sounds like a risky business. 4. Regulatory Science Methods Related to Algorithm Bias & Robustness My take: This is why we expected that the FDA would take over our open access database of A.I.-based medical devices that we published in Nature Publishing Group's npj Digital Medicine paper. However, they confirmed to me that they won’t. 5. Real-World Performance  My take: The FDA should promote the importance of prospective studies when it comes to analyzing algorithms' performance in medical tasks.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:How will the digitalization of healthcare impact bedside communication and patient relations among medical professionals, and what strategies should professionals adopt to successfully navigate this transformed clinical landscape? [/INST] ‘Webside’ instead of bedside: a new, digital way of communicating with patients. I keep highlighting the need for a cultural transformation in healthcare to catch up with the digital transformation (rapidly accelerated by COVID-19).  Kaiser Permanente’s new curriculum is a wonderful example: instead of only teaching students the necessary bedside communication skills that each medical professional learns, they now integrate the “webside” manner. They want to prepare students for a clinical practice likely to be far more virtual than ever before, as there’ll be less bedside visits and shaking hands, and more virtual interactions. Still, communication and creating a connection with patients is such a key element of medicine, and since digital communication is something different, it needs to be learnt.  Well done! <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Which COVID-19 vaccine should one choose based on reputable scientific evidence rather than political influence or marketing efforts? [/INST] Which vaccine will I want to get? This is one of the questions I get the most. In the UK, the first 130,000 people got vaccinated against COVID-19. The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine just got approved in the US, and we’re waiting for the authorization of the Moderna vaccine as well. I expect to get the vaccine around May as luckily I’m not considered to be part of the high risk category. So what’s my answer? I’ll get the vaccine about which I can read a study. Since I see the studies for both the Pfizer-BioNTech and the Moderna, I could choose either.  Whereas I don’t see any for either the Russian or the Chinese vaccine. A decision about a vaccine should never, ever be about which political power is communicating about it louder than others.  It has to be a competent pharma company with a study, peer reviewed and published in a medical journal, approved by a regulatory agency. We all understand the rush and the pressure, but despite all this, medical clinical evidence is a must. And I stand by this forever. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #COVID19   #COVID_19   #coronavirus

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:How can the principles of empathy developed in physical healthcare spaces be applied and redefined in the unique digital context of patient-provider interactions, and what implications does this have for healthcare policy and medical practice? [/INST] Empathy in the digital space: this is something crucial that we all need to learn from zero in healthcare as well. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the limitations and potential flaws of using AI algorithms in medical diagnostics, particularly when it comes to expiry date of study results in medical AI assessments? [/INST] Here we go again: Big words in the headline while the study was retrospective. A study from Northwestern University concludes that DeepCOVID-XR, an A.I. algorithm they’ve developed, detected COVID-19 on chest X-rays with performance similar to a consensus of experienced thoracic radiologists. However, when you look into the details, you see it was trained on data retrospectively.  Whereas a physician diagnoses and treats a patient real-time, and doing that retrospectively would yield very different results and efficiency. I think study authors should only compare an algorithm's performance to that of physicians if both used the same method to diagnose or treat, prospectively. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Can a clinically-based deep learning algorithm reduce unnecessary overnight monitoring of patients in hospitals, thereby improving recovery outcomes by providing more personalized and efficient care? [/INST] Interrupted sleep is terrible! Interrupted sleep while being in a hospital can straightaway slow your recovery. Now an artificial intelligence based algorithm can help avoid that. Many patients get woken up at night or at dawn to have their blood pressure measured or blood tested. When all they should be doing is to rest.  Researchers of this paper mean to avoid these unnecessary overnight monitoring, using a clinically based deep learning model. They’ve checked millions of data from a multi-hospital health system to train an algorithm that creates an early morning patient score: this shows who are those patients that really need to be woken up due to a risky condition. Their result? From 10,000 cases, the algorithm was wrong only 2 times.  This is exactly the kind of clinical problem where we need to start A.I. research and implementation. This is so very convincing that it could enable the adoption of artificial intelligence in other areas as well.  #deeplearning   #research   #hospitalcare   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #machinelearning

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are your top non-fiction picks of 2020 that offer insightful perspectives on AI, technology, and society? [/INST] You know how much time and effort I dedicate to choose what to read next? (That’s right, a LOT).  So who doesn’t love a good old “Best of” book list? 🕮 Here are my top picks of non-fiction from 2020. What was your favorite one this year? Human Compatible by  Stuart Russell  - Provides the perfect context and historical background to understand where A.I. is coming from.  The Logic Of Failure by Dietrich Dorner -  Learning about how and why we fail and more importantly, why it is understandable in many situations to fail is a new experience.  You Look Like a Thing and I Love You by  Janelle Shane  - It showed me what A.I. is really capable of today (and what it’s not). Rebooting AI by  Gary Marcus  - A clear view about the big picture of A.I., how it will impact our lives and what we can do to protect what matters: our life, privacy and freedom.  Possible Minds: Twenty-Five Ways of Looking at AI by John Brockman - A collection of essays about different aspects and fields of A.I.  The Revolt of The Public and the Crisis of Authority in the New Millennium by Martin Gurri - A new angle on our society today.  How Virtual Therapeutics Will Revolutionize Medicine by  Brennan Spiegel, MD, MSHS  - Everything that matters on VR in healthcare.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What implications does the growing use of wearable technology for monitoring and predicting COVID-related health issues have on the future of personalized medicine and patient outcomes? [/INST] Finally, the study we’ve been waiting for since the beginning of the pandemic is out! It obtained data from wearable trackers from over 30,000 people to find out whether the data can be used to differentiate between asymptomatic and symptomatic COVID patients. They also aimed at spotting pre-symptomatic individuals early. "Our results show that individual changes in physiological measures captured by most smartwatches and activity trackers are able to significantly improve the distinction between symptomatic individuals with and without a diagnosis of COVID-19 beyond symptoms alone." They will keep on expanding the cohort but it’s already a staggering result and shows a bright vision for digital health.  Can you imagine a world where the health technologies we use alert us about upcoming health issues similarly to the warning lights in your car? I can. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Describe a real-world application of artificial intelligence in healthcare to improve patient outcomes, including the development process and its significant impact. [/INST] This is my favourite story these days. This is how you develop and deploy an A.I.-based algorithm for a clinical purpose. Sepsis Watch is the product of three and a half years of development (which included digitizing health records, analyzing 32 million data points, and designing a simple interface in the form of an iPad app).  It scores patients on an hourly basis for their likelihood of developing sepsis (when an infection triggers full-body inflammation and causes organs to shut down). It then flags those who are medium or high risk and those who already meet the criteria. Once a doctor confirms the diagnosis, the patients get immediate attention. It has dramatically reduced sepsis-induced patient deaths and is now part of a federally registered clinical trial expected to share its results in 2021. #healthcare   #aihealthcare   #digitalhealth   #artificialintelligence

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the findings of the qualitative interviews with digitally engaged physicians on their attitudes towards the impact of digital health technologies on the doctor-patient relationship and the future of medical practice? [/INST] I was a co-author of this paper published in PLOS One. We aimed to explore the digitally engaged physician’s knowledge and attitudes towards digital health technologies and the transformation of the doctor-patient relationship. We did this by doing qualitative, semi-structured interviews with 11 digitally engaged physicians from 9 countries.  We asked them about the role of digital health and technology in the medical practice and their everyday challenges, the ideal physician-patient relationship, and skills and competencies needed for working with e-patients and visions about the future of the medical practice. The interviewed physicians state that digital health solutions could create a deeper doctor-patient relationship: knowledgeable patients are a huge help in the joint work effort and technology is the main tool for creating a more involved and responsible patient.  Medical professionals in the future might rather get a role as a translator between technical data and the patient; as a guide in the jungle of digital health. However, the interviewed physicians also noted that digital transition today is more beneficial to patients than to their doctors. #digitalhealth   #futureofhealthcare   #study

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Researchers are utilizing Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) to generate labeled, undyed CT images for training AI diagnostic models, offering a potential solution to the lack of sufficient high-quality labeled medical data. [/INST] While I write often about the limitations of artificial intelligence and what it can really offer in practice today, sometimes I come across developments in A.I. that not only blow my mind away but also depict an exciting vision of the future of healthcare. Look at this: In some cases, patients need injections with an iodine-based dye (radiocontrast) to make their organs more visible in scans. But some patients can’t take the dye. So researchers developed a GAN (generative adversarial network) that generates labeled, undyed CT images of lesions on kidneys, spleens, and livers. They added these images to real-world training data to improve performance of a segmentation model that marks lesions in diagnostic scans. As it's really hard to get enough quality medical data to train the algorithm on and labeled medical data is even harder to find, GANs are making it easier and less expensive to create large, annotated datasets for training A.I. diagnostic tools.   #artificialintelligence   #ai   #aihealthcare   #digitalhealth   #futureofhealthcare   #themedicalfuturist

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Despite the potential benefits of digital health tools, the term "virtual care" may be alienating and misrepresenting the actual nature of care, highlighting the need for a broader examination of how to improve care in general, rather than focusing solely on the differences between virtual and in-person models. [/INST] Accenture released a report based on a survey that around 2000 participants filled out in the US. They conclude that before COVID-19, growth in consumer digital health adoption had stalled. While the cohort is small and only US-based, I understand the criticism around digital health tools and services. My main concern is that they call it virtual care. I have a great relationship with my GP, and when I share some data with her about a potential health issue and she helps via digital communication, I don't feel that it's different from when she attends me in person. Digital health in the eyes of its users and medical professionals will always look like something that doesn't want to work, while the solution's been here all along: whether you provide care in person or by using a way of digital communication, it's just care. Stop calling it virtual care, stop alienating this from everyday medicine and accept that digital health will bring a cultural transformation. This is the new norm where the use of technologies is inevitable in caring for patients. This misconceptualization derails the whole study. Instead of emphasizing the differences between virtual and in-person care, it should examine ways to improve care in general. And that question is independent from technologies.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:As a pediatrician, I was eager to evaluate StethoMe, the A.I.-enabled digital stethoscope, in my practice and share my thoughts, including both its benefits and limitations, such as how portable it is, its ease of use, and how the AI algorithm improves the examination process. [/INST] I asked Dr.  Ádám Schmidt  to test  StethoMe® , the A.I.-enabled digital stethoscope in his pediatrician practice, and here are his observations: "StethoMe is probably a dream device for parents and for doctors to follow up on pulmonary and cardiac diseases. The device is portable, mostly for home use, is sleek and has no buttons to confuse the user. The StethoMe app gives the user comprehensive advice on what and how to do during the examination. The auscultation is recorded with the device and sent via Bluetooth to the phone app, which uploads it to the cloud and is analyzed by the StethoMe AI algorithm. It can be time-consuming and difficult to complete a good enough examination, especially when a child is crying. The StethoMe AI algorithm can’t filter the surrounding noise, and the device itself is quite loud too - because of that, home use can be tricky. Overall, I like the device and find it useful. It can be used at home to decide on the status of your patient. I find it very useful that you can record and play back previous recordings, creating a timeline of data to monitor the evolution of the disease. As an addition, with this function it is easier to teach medical students and educate patients. Looking forward to the progression of the device." #DigitalHealth

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Discuss the implications of a smartphone-based algorithm for detecting Type 2 diabetes and how it could revolutionize the field of digital biomarkers, generating early detection and potentially improving management of the chronic disease. [/INST] Last year,  Peter Kuhar , founder of  Azumio Inc. , reached out to me with some preliminary data showing Type 2 diabetes detection with just a smartphone. Now Nature Medicine published their study. To me, it shows how to turn a promise into a proof, also giving a boost to digital biomarkers. I had a quick chat with him. - Can you please summarize the findings of your study? We've developed an algorithm that can detect diabetes using heart pulse recorded by a smartphone camera. Enabling an early detection of Type 2 diabetes with just a smartphone. - How do you expect the field of biomarkers to change based on studies like yours? Digital biomarkers are easy and low cost to measure and have a potential to allow early detection of diseases that would otherwise not be possible. One of the main problems with Type 2 diabetes is late diagnosis. Our algorithm will help catch this chronic disease faster. - Do you think that the hardware of a general smartphone would be enough to add insights to diabetes management? Absolutely. The hardware with this capability is available since 2014 on iPhone, and lately more and more and more Android devices are getting this capability. #DigitalHealth   #DigitalBiomarkers   #T2D   #Diabetes

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are some commonly promoted digital health gadgets and services that I should approach with a healthy dose of skepticism, and why? [/INST] Being digital and portable doesn't guarantee that a device will be useful. I usually show services and devices that I heartily recommend, but now here's a friendly warning about gadgets you should be cautious about - they might be just (digital) dog and pony shows! 1. Calorie count from photos. You take a photo of your food and the app tells you the nutrients it contains. It's not even accurate when you weigh portions of your food and add those to an app like MyFitnessPal, so imagine how accurate those could be, using only photos. 2. Cheap tools to measure heart rate and sleep quality. If you want to take your tracking endeavors up a notch, you can't succeed with a single app or device just above the very basic level. 3. Pulse oximetry apps. You can install them for free on your phone, but unfortunately they are inaccurate - even studies show. 4. Genetic ancestry tests. It's thrilling to take one. But don't try to gain any medical insights from it. And definitely don't try to prove anything with it at your visa application. 5. Multifunction devices that can measure your vital signs, earthquakes, and the mood of your family. Maybe even killing mosquitoes. If something sounds too good to be true, it is. Which  #DigitalHealth  service didn't live up to its promises for you?

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are some promising holiday gadgets and apps that track vital signs, environmental factors, and your body's response to ensure a safe and enjoyable vacation? [/INST] Our holiday-related Instagram quiz sparkled a lot of interest. Is it really true that such a patch exists that alerts you before you get sunburnt? What's the name of the device that buzzes for dehydration? And so on. So here you are, my hitchhiker's (and vacationer's) guide to holidays! About wristbands that measure water in your blood with infrared light: I don't believe they are accurate enough (if they're not accurate for heart rate, forget about proper hydration levels). Apps that regularly remind you to drink water to avoid dehydration: You might be surprised, but I don't think we need a device for every drop of fluid, every blink, and every breath we take. But, challenge me if you know any concrete cases one needs a ding-ding for each glass of water. Wearable patches that measure sun exposure and notify the user when they are about to get sunburnt: I haven't seen that in practice - as far as I know,  L'Oréal  only came out with it as a pilot. I would gladly try them though! Dermatology apps that identify rashes and mysterious insect bites: I have tried  First Derm by iDoc24  and I've had a good experience with them. It definitely won't hurt if you download it before setting off! #DigitalHealth   #Holidays   #DigitalHealthApps   #HealthTech   #FutureOfHealthcare

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:I recently tested the ReliefHeat device to alleviate low back pain, but its effectiveness varies depending on individual needs, and I share my findings on its usability, features, pain relief capabilities, and limitations. [/INST] If you've never had back pain, don't read on. If you sometimes do, you are probably looking for some relief for it. Something that's easy to manage, portable, user-friendly, and durable. And most importantly, it has to reduce pain. I just tested Reliefheat, a device that promises exactly these. This is my experience with it: - The belt is easy to use, comfortable and portable. - The device operates on an app where you can set the basic features via Bluetooth. It heats and changes temperature in seconds and even learns your preferences. Charging is quick and battery life is long. - But: you need to figure out first if heat works for you or not. Everyone reacts to the same treatment differently. Heat might alleviate your muscle and joint problems, but for inflammation you should stick with something cold. - ReliefHeat is designed for the lower back area and although I tried to use it on other body parts, like knees and shoulders, it didn’t work out well and was uncomfortable. - The product is only available in the US and Canada. All in all, ReliefHeat delivered on its promises. If I had chronic back pain that reacted to heat, it would be an instant buy. But if the pain is elsewhere, or heat did not make you feel better, I would recommend you finding another option. 
 
 
 …see more </s>

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What practical strategies can Lancet Digital Health, The Medical Futurist, and other stakeholders develop to mitigate racial bias in digital health approaches and ensure more equitable healthcare outcomes? [/INST] This is a great illustration of how significant the cultural transformation with digital health is. Lancet Digital Health published an editorial addressing the issue of race to end health inequalities. They stated that racial and gender bias represent a significant problem in digital health, and even digital health approaches have contributed to these disparities by not considering race or ethnicity. "For example, melanoma diagnostic apps trained on images of white skin have difficulty detecting cancerous skin lesions in darker skin. Even failing to sufficiently account for variables that are correlated with race, such as health-care expenditure, can create a wedge between health needs and care received. When race clearly plays a causative role in health outcomes it should be incorporated into digital health approaches to prevent bias." And here, at pointing to a serious flaw, science stopped so far. What practical ideas would you give us and Lancet to fight racial injustice in digital health? We, at  The Medical Futurist , support these efforts, and I hope that we could come up with relevant analyses or research soon. Source:  https://lnkd.in/erEMKea #DigitalHealth   #RacialBias   #AIBias   #BiasInHealthcare   #GenderBias 
 
 
 …see more </s>

So, she created a one-pager where she included bits and pieces about her personal and professional life. Fallow listed what technologies and social media she uses, trackers such as Fitbit, Garmin or Strava. She even entered all the resources and assets that help her manage her condition, starting from her supportive partner until the medical alert dog. She described what symptoms she struggles with and what her current goals are regarding managing her illness. It is clear, concise and might be very helpful to doctors. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the key implications of recent major company hacks on consumer data privacy and how to prepare for emerging challenges in digitized health technologies? [/INST] Garmin's recent hacking shows just a foretaste of how it is like when hackers target multibillion-dollar companies with sensitive consumer data. This time, the hackers didn't steal user data, but it was just a matter of luck. Some of those functions are subject to FDA’s regulatory oversight as medical devices, while others are not. I read the whole thing so you don't have to. When they regulate a medical device, the so-called "other functions" may jeopardize the cybersecurity, reliability or accuracy of the device. So they want to make sure that those other functions are also regulated, and the industry is aware of the dangers and risks so the FDA can have a better oversight over such devices too. As technologies get more advanced with artificial intelligence-based analysis, using smartphones or other connected devices, it was time to address this so patients and medical professionals can still use such technologies with trust. The best example they mention at the end is about a smartphone app that detects skin cancer from photos of suspicious lesions of moles. They describe that the quality of the photo a phone camera can make significantly shapes the outcome of the analysis. The manufacturer of the app should document how the camera impacts their app's accuracy. Excellent step forward! #FDAregulation   #HealthcareRegulation

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Can you think of subtle yet crucial observational biases existing in data used to train AI algorithms in various fields, from medicine to industry, leading to potential false positives, false negatives, and algorithmic errors? [/INST] Researchers at the University of Tübingen tried to train an A.I. to learn to identify a specific fish called tench on pictures. When they looked into the A.I. to see how it tries to identify that fish, they found out that the  #AI  was looking for human fingers against a green background as most of the tench photos in the training data featured a fisherman holding the fish in their hands after catching it. Can you imagine how useful it would be in medicine to point out such things before an algorithm is developed? This way, we could avoid so many false negatives, false positives and bias built into the algorithms. For example, radiologists looked at the ChestXray14 dataset of X-ray images and discovered that many of the images of patients with pneumothorax had a chest drain on the image as treatment already started when doing the X-ray. A  #MachineLearning  algorithm tasked with identifying X-rays of pneumothorax would probably look for the drain in the images as a perfect sign of the condition (they have to perform as well as humans would do, not learn to diagnose the condition), this way, missing patients with the condition who have not been treated yet. Can you think of an example in your practice (medical or not) where such subtle observations exist?

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Compare the effectiveness of anonymization versus pseudonymization in protecting patient privacy in medical datasets, highlighting the limitations and potential alternatives. [/INST] I just came across a great paper describing the difference between anonymization vs pseudonymization. Both represent important methods for protecting the privacy of patients whose data take part in studies and are analyzed by artificial intelligence. Currently, these are the most widely used privacy preservation techniques for medical datasets: 1) Anonymization is the removal of private data from a medical record. Simply, they delete parts of data such as name, gender or age. 2) Pseudonymization is the replacement of sensitive entries with artificially generated ones. They simply replace data such as name, gender or age with synthetic ones. It's harder than it sounds. Interestingly, the paper concludes that "De-identification by naive anonymization or pseudonymization alone must therefore be viewed as a technically insufficient measure against identity inference." But authors don't leave us in the dark, but recommend techniques that can indeed enhance patients' privacy. Check it out: #ArtificialIntelligence   #privacy   #anonymization   #pseudonymization   #HealthData

After all, I lead a healthy lifestyle, work out regularly, have social relationships - I consider myself an outgoing, happy person with a healthy attitude. It was only these past few months that I started experiencing fatigue and anxiety, and I even lost my motivation because of the feeling of hopelessness and uncertainty. I shouldn't wonder, because these are hopeless and uncertain times, which causes symptoms of depression to more than half (!) of us - as several studies show. Even the WHO put together a brief on mental health considerations during COVID-19, with tailored messages not only to caregivers, but also to the general public. Of course, digital health companies also joined in the efforts. UK-based startup UnMind provides a platform for workplace mental health, Headspace is specializing in meditation, while Big Health offers a digital sleep improvement program to help overcome poor sleep without pills. It seems we will experiment with YouTube Live first. * He shared how he "branded" his audience, started calling them by a name that is unique to his channel. * He described how hard it is to maintain contact with them and keep them engaged while sitting in front of a camera and a green screen with his hands on the keyboard and mouse. * He hasn't used a biometric sensor but some of his colleagues have showing their pulse during intense gaming moments. * Many streaming services have a significant lag (even almost a minute) which would make a live Q&A unbearable. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:How is artificial intelligence revolutionizing radiology and making healthcare faster and more efficient through innovative medical imaging technologies? [/INST] Artificial intelligence has been enjoying a boom in certain medical specialties and radiology always stands out. There is an interesting story in MIT Tech Review about what A.I. is capable of in imaging. Rizwan Malik, radiologist at the Royal Bolton Hospital, turned to A.I. to make his job easier. In his hospital, patients often had to wait six hours or more for a specialist to look at their x-rays. If an emergency room doctor could get an initial reading from an A.I.-based tool, it could dramatically shrink that wait time. A specialist could follow up the A.I. system’s reading later. So last year, Malik identified a promising A.I.-based chest x-ray system called qXR from  Qure.ai  and proposed to test the system over six months. As COVID-19 jumped into our lives, they also had to re-design the system that now is capable of identifying coronavirus-specific signs. Such a fast response and iteration is only possible in the case of A.I.-based medical technologies. This is why it's so crucial that the FDA, for example, started analyzing companies instead of individual algorithms for approval. Also, there are so many COVID-19 related ongoing A.I. projects in medical imaging, that Stanford started to curate many:  https://lnkd.in/gE_rdhP #themedicalfuturist   #AI

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What implications do poor reporting and bias in AI prediction models for COVID-19 diagnosis, prognosis, and hospital risk assessment have for the reliable implementation of AI in clinical practice and the future of digital healthcare? [/INST] A rapid systematic review just came out in the  BMJ . It aimed at reviewing and critically appraising reports of prediction models for 1) diagnosing coronavirus disease 2019 (covid-19) in patients with suspected infection, 2) for prognosis of patients with covid-19, and 3) for detecting people in the general population at risk of being admitted to hospital for covid-19-related pneumonia. It's quite devastating what it found and clearly shows why implementing A.I. into the clinical practice is going to be so hard without evidence-based data. They found that the proposed models are poorly reported, at high risk of bias, and their reported performance is probably optimistic. Only one study used patient data from outside of China. We have to exclude hype from those papers and push the medical/scientific community to stick to the standards of reporting about A.I.-based technologies. https://lnkd.in/g_xfSrg #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #covid19   #coronavirus

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Describe how the COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the adoption of 'digital health' technologies, turning a crisis into a transformative moment for healthcare innovation. [/INST] A note for those who don't understand why we had to shut the world down for this pandemic. This new virus led to a significant death toll in weeks, there are no treatment protocols, or thousands of peer-reviewed studies, no experience and knowledge in textbooks. Therefore, we had to shut down the world to let the medical workforce do its best until they can deal with it. Without the lockdowns, there would be peaks of cases in the span of days, leading to tens of millions of avoidable deaths, an overwhelmed medical workforce, and even mroe uncertainty about when we can go back to our lives. All this turns out to be a moment for  #digitalhealth  to shine. Telemedicine has become the norm in many countries to avoid exposure to infections. 3D printing technologies help support the broken supply chains of medical and protective equipment. Chatbots help those who face mental health challenges. Artificial intelligence helps prepare for the spread of the virus, reorganize supplies and help prioritize patients at higher risk for a severe disease. Apps all over the digital health specturm assist those who stay at home and still try to live a healthy lifestyle. As the pandemic passes, and it will, I hope the openness for these technologies will remain with us forever. #covid19

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What opportunities and challenges emerged for businesses and individuals in the healthcare and technology sectors during the COVID-19 pandemic, and how have they adapted and innovated as a result? [/INST] How many of you had to reconsider your overall business model and functioning due to COVID-19? By putting all events on hold and upsetting healthcare and life in general, we at The Medical Futurist definitely did. We turned this junction into an opportunity to create an online community on Patreon, where I share high-quality, exclusive content, and we can even experiment with new forms of communication (a long-time dream come true!). If you join our Patreon community, you can not only contribute to the further activities of The Medical Futurist but also partake of personal analyses, short videos, a podcast and various other things you don't find elsewhere. This way, public health officials can see how effective social distancing measures are in 131 countries. The announcement mentions that Google isn't releasing any data on individual people or specific locations. Instead, "it used differential privacy techniques to add noise to the data sets used to create the reports in an effort to make it harder to de-anonymize that data used to create the reports." It means it's possible to deanonymize data, in theory, even though the risk is small. I'm so glad such huge data sets can support the fight against the pandemic, but we have to be vigilant so beating the pandemic doesn't come with the loss of our privacy. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What if antibodies become a requirement for everyday life after a pandemic, forcing governments to implement a system of biological passports and immunity checks for people to safely reintegrate into society? [/INST] The FDA just approved an antibody-based test for COVID-19 which raises interesting issues. Those patients who are infected with the virus produce antibodies specific to the virus and such tests can detect them. This would show who has already been sick — whether they had symptoms or not — and therefore, who is probably immune enough to the virus to safely move around.  It doesn't mean the test is helpful during the pandemic but it could be useful when we try to go back to living our lives and doing our jobs. I'm just speculating here: What if the pandemic goes on for many months from now even with the worldwide lockdowns and only those people would be allowed to reduce social distancing (to work, do shopping, travel, etc.) who has a positive antibody test and a negative virus test (a PCR test showing there is no coronavirus in their body)? What if biotech companies have to create a sort of biological passport so some people can go back to society? I hope it'd only happen if the worst pandemic scenarios take place. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #COVID19   #COVID_19   #coronavirus

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Describe the potential benefits and applications of creating a digital twin of the human body for the purposes of medical research, treatment, and patient care. [/INST] A digital twin is a virtual copy of a tangible entity or an intangible system that can be analyzed independently of its real-world counterpart in order to make informed decisions. NASA employed a similar concept when it created physical replicas of its spacecrafts on Earth while the actual ones were in outer space. The same concept can be applied to medicine too: a virtual representation of the human body and its organs where the effects of drugs can be studied. And its impact can be revolutionary. #themedicalfuturist #digitalhealth #future #healthcare #medicine #technology #fromchancetochoice #digitaltwins #digitaltwin #personalizedmedicine

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Have you noticed any significant time reductions in emergency department wait times through innovative matching algorithms like the one used by Maple for Health PEI researchers understand the impact of such technology adoption in emergency medicine [/INST] I just came across a company called Maple that developed a virtual care program that tries to reduce the burden on the staff in emergency departments. They are piloting it with  Health PEI , a governmental organization.   Some patients who meet the program’s specific inclusion and exclusion criteria can use a virtual care visit right on the spot, instead of waiting for in-person treatment. The nursing staff under medical directives can perform a few tests, then add data about the patient on the online platform. This request goes out to a network of physicians using an Uber-like matching approach and physicians determine if they’d like to “pick up the visit” and treat the patient.  They reported an incredible drop in waiting times - down from 8 hours in some cases to under 5 minutes because of their matching algorithm and triage approach. I know there are many emergency physicians here. What is your experience with such solutions? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #ER   #emergencymedicine

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the innovative applications of deep learning in the medical field, particularly in surgery and cancer diagnostics? [/INST] A new technique based on deep learning can shorten some brain surgeries. During brain cancer operations, surgeons must stop in mid-operation for up to half an hour while they send the tissue to the lab where a pathologist analyzes it. A new test powered by deep learning does the same but within the operating room, with spectroscopy, and in only a few minutes. They trained the network to recognize 13 cancer types that account for around 90 percent of observed brain tumors and measured its performance in a clinical trial (the first trial of a deep learning application in the operating room, they said). <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Will the impending FDA approval of a cure for peanut allergy be eclipsed by advancements in affordable and environmentally friendly food allergy testing technologies like Nima Labs's sensor, or will innovation in medical research ultimately outpace practical applications in this field? [/INST] The FDA just approved the first drug to treat 4-17 years old children having peanut allergies. It's designed to minimize the incidence and severity of a child's allergic reaction to peanuts. In the US, 2.5% of children have peanut allergy, but millions of people are affected worldwide. For some, eating food containing peanut - whether denied by clueless waiters or mislabelled on the package - can even be lethal. So when I say that sensors indicating whether a food has peanut can be very useful, I mean literally life-saving. In this category, I tested  Nima Labs 's sensor (they also have one for gluten), and it does the task flawlessly - if you put a small sample of food in it, it indicates peanut accurately, is truly easy and fast to use, and it's portable. The only flip side is that you have to change capsules for each sampling, which is neither economical nor environmentally friendly. So, at the moment, it's not without fault - but neither is the newly approved treatment.  Which do you think will come true first: the perfect cure for peanut allergy or economical and environmentally friendly testers? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #medicine   #technology   #nima   #glutensensor   #peanutsensor   #glutensensitivity   #glutenintolerance   #peanutallergy   #foodintolerance   #foodallergy

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Can AI-driven health monitoring systems like BlueDot Inc effectively reduce the risk and impact of pandemics by leveraging vast amounts of publicly available data and predicting potential outbreaks early on? [/INST] Another excellent example of how A.I.-based systems could help improve healthcare. On January 9, the WHO notified the public of a flu-like outbreak in China. But a Canadian health monitoring platform,  BlueDot Inc  , sent word of the outbreak to its customers on December 31. It uses an AI-driven algorithm that scours foreign-language news reports, animal and plant disease networks, airline ticketing data and official proclamations to give its clients advance warning to avoid danger zones like Wuhan. It also correctly predicted that the virus would jump from Wuhan to Bangkok, Seoul, Taipei, and Tokyo in the days following its initial appearance. There is so much data that even the most experienced experts are not able to deal with it or see everything while these algorithms can filter through the mess of information. I hope governments and global organizations will take advantage of them. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #wuhan   #coronavirus   #epidemics

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the limitations and potential pitfalls of relying on artificial intelligence algorithms in medical decision-making, and how can physicians effectively integrate them into clinical practice? [/INST] I couldn't have come up with a better example to demonstrate how an artificial intelligence-based system will support the job of physicians than the recent paper from Google Health.  Even the head of Google Health UK said that such algorithms support the job of physicians, not replace them. So please don't believe the hype when you read the headlines such as A.I. outperforms physicians in diagnosing a medical condition.  1) These usually take place on pre-selected data sets, and clinical life is much more diverse than that.  2) Many of these studies are retrospective and still have to prove the efficiency of the algorithm prospectively. Just one of the reasons why I have a keynote narrative entirely dedicated to understanding A.I. from the medical and healthcare perspective. Those working with A.I. algorithms must understand at least the basics and it is indeed possible without any prior knowledge. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #mammography   #googlehealth   #speaker   #speakerlife   #keynotespeaker

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What emerging digital health technologies and innovative approaches could potentially transform the pharmaceutical development process, making it more efficient, accessible, and affordable for patients worldwide? <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Describe the potential impact of an ultra-miniature injectable sensor capable of continuously tracking intra-ocular pressure on the field of ophthalmic drug development. [/INST] Glaucoma is tough to treat. One of the only indicators of progression for this blinding disease is intra-ocular pressure which squeezes and damages the optical nerve. Injectsense hopes to change this scenario with an ultra-miniature injectable sensor that will track your eye pressure continuously over years, with the resulting data telling doctors what treatment is effective and what is not. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Discuss the current state of medical image diagnosis studies and their limitations, highlighting the growing potential of machine learning to improve healthcare. [/INST] There are some exiting studies that came out in the last 1-2 weeks. Topol's team compared the accuracy of deep learning algorithms to that of medical professionals in making diagnoses on medical images. Besides giving a comprehensive overview of the field (without any hype), they pointed out 5 major issues with those studies. 1) most studies took the approach of assessing diagnostic accuracy in isolation not reflecting clinical practice 2) there were very few prospective studies done in real clinical environments 3) a wide range of metrics were employed to report diagnostic performance 4) there is inconsistency over key terminology 5) most studies did not do an out-of-sample validation for both health-care professionals and deep learning algorithms Read it here:  https://lnkd.in/gFVPT4u Also, some other news: Machine learning could offer faster, more precise results for cardiac MRI scans  http://bit.ly/2oPXnqA Prediction system for risk of allograft loss in patients receiving kidney transplants: international derivation and valhttps://lnkd.in/gyTbbUU #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Describe a hypothetical scenario where a non-expert developer creates a highly regarded medical algorithm, explaining how randomly generated data and self-serving reinforcement learning processes enabled their creation. [/INST] It was really hard to track down the developers of Leela Chess Zero, the highest rated chess engine today, but I managed to find them in a developer forum. It was interesting to learn that the developers are not professional chess players and they don't even need to be to develop such an algorithm.  Imagine the same in medicine. Developers creating the highest rated medical algorithm without having a profound knowledge of medicine. This is the era artificial intelligence is bringing to us. Here is how they described the algorithm works: "Leela Chess uses a neural network trained without human knowledge. The training procedure uses reinforcement learning to train the next generation of the network based on games played using the previous one against itself (“self-play”) so without any external influence. The initial network is trained using random games so there is no human input in the process. The next network improvement comes from using a (small) search tree to improve the neural network’s evaluation of a position and using this outcome, together with the game result, to train the next network. Any principles used during play are discovered this way, but not in a way that can be easily extracted as such. Obviously, the rules of chess are hard-coded in the engine."

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What's the real-world practicality and effectiveness of the Sleepon sleep tracker after a full week of consistent use, with a detailed analysis of its performance in tracking vital signs and waking the user up when oxygen levels drop? [/INST] I said yes (to sleep tracking). I've tested around 20 sleep sensors including masks, watches and devices going under the mattress. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:I recently received the results of my genetic test with Atlas Biomed and I'd like to share my experience of understanding the dataset, particularly the disease risks and hereditary disease carrier status, and discuss how this has impacted my plans for prevention and future testing. [/INST] I received the results of my genetic test with Atlas Biomed. I thought I'd share all the results piece by piece here before publishing the big review on  medicalfuturist.com . Part I. Disease risks They analyzed a lot of polymorphisms in my DNA that have been associated with disease risks. I discussed that with their genetic counselor and she also made it clear that it matters which studies a certain company chooses to base their estimations on. In my case, I have high risk for three conditions (coronary heart disease, ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease). I've seen these in other genetic tests before but my high melanoma risk was not included in the report as they don't check for polymorphisms in cancer. The "average risk" conditions I have are quite common across populations.  Regarding hereditary diseases, I don't carry any of the about 200 conditions they check for. It doesn't mean it's a 100% I don't carry those gene variants but there is a big chance for that. To check for a specific condition, I'd need a more detailed genetic test.  Conclusion: to discuss the prevention plan about coronary heart disease with my GP. In the next posts, I'd describe my nutrition, sports and personal traits & my microbiome analysis. #genetics   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What did you wish you knew before embarking on your career, and how has your journey as a speaker evolved to meet the changing demands of the 21st century? [/INST] What do you wish you knew before starting your career? I just finished Confessions of a public speaker, a book every speaker should read. I stopped keeping track of how many presentations and keynotes I have given after 500. The book made me think about the one thing that I would have loved to know before even giving a speech. The example I saw back then was that you make a breakthrough (in science, in business, or by publishing a great book, etc.) and then you can ride that wave for many years. I've seen good speakers give the same talk many times. The truth is that in the 21st century it doesn't work. Being a speaker today means that you constantly refresh yourself and the content you present while also making it as spectacular as possible. You have to entertain while keeping your integrity (especially critical for me talking about healthcare). It's a pressing challenge but I've been enjoying this ""ride"" for long. Along these lines, my new keynote narrative entirely dedicated to artificial intelligence in medicine comes out this September. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the essential needs and future expectations of opinion leaders in the digital healthcare landscape that their physicians should prioritize? <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What responsibilities should be assigned to developers, regulators, and physicians when an artificial intelligence algorithm used in medical decision-making makes a mistake, and what can be learned from the liability implications of a faulty stethoscope or medical device? [/INST] Yesterday, I gave a keynote about artificial intelligence's role in healthcare to a biopharma company. One of the best questions I received was about liability. Who is to blame if an A.I. algorithm makes a mistake? This is a recurring issue and I like to answer it with a metaphor. If a physician listens to your heart sounds with a stethoscope and there was something wrong with the device and it misled the diagnosis, who is to blame? The manufacturer of the stethoscope? Never. The physician is supposed to be using all the available technologies at their disposal and with their expertise and knowledge therefore only they can be blamed, the final decision is their responsibility.  The same applies to the use of A.I. It is a (regulated, supervised and assessed) tool in the physician's hand and thus only contributes to the decisions, not making them.  What do you think? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Describe the implications of the Moravec paradox in the field of artificial intelligence and its potential impact on the development of medical technologies, highlighting the importance of patience and incremental progress in creating intelligent machines. [/INST] Moravec paradox represents a super exciting issue in the world of artificial intelligence. It basically says that high-level reasoning requires much less computation than low-level sensorimotor skills. In short, it's easier to write a program to be the CEO of a major company than to be a coal miner.  As Hans Moravec writes, "it is comparatively easy to make computers exhibit adult level performance on intelligence tests or playing checkers, and difficult or impossible to give them the skills of a one-year-old when it comes to perception and mobility". Regarding the A.I. era of medicine, it might mean that it makes more sense to teach an algorithm to get better at certain skills important for us working in healthcare than expect programmers to write a code that can do it right away. Meaning we have to be very patient with algorithm when they come to medicine. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #TMFchessjourney 
 
 
 …see more </s>

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are your key takeaways when evaluating papers on machine and deep learning algorithms proposed for medical applications, including considerations around publication, methods, data quality, and clinical collaboration? [/INST] Very promising papers come out every day about machine and deep learning algorithms used for medical and healthcare purposes and this field is just blowing up. I received questions from physician colleagues who are not A.I. experts about how they should evaluate these papers. I thought I would share a few things I do myself. - It matters where the paper is published. It's not scientific elitism but it matters if a new algorithm gets presented in Nature Medicine or in a third level journal. - Look for the Methods section where they describe where they got the data. No algorithm can be trained without a good amount of quality data. Some groups just use a good dataset and do tricks on it to make it bigger (e.g. invert images to double the database size). That's not the same as getting a huge amount of annotated data. - Look for the clinical collaboration they had. If an algorithm works well on a pre-selected dataset, that sounds fine. But when it works on clinical datasets too, that is the one we are looking for. When I saw @ DeepMind  collaborating closely with the NHS, I knew that was the right direction. Can you please share the tricks you use while assessing a medical A.I. paper? #digitalhealth   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #TMFchessjourney 
 
 
 …see more </s>

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the essential needs and future expectations of opinion leader empowered patients when interacting with their physicians amidst the rise of digital health technologies? [/INST] We aimed to explore the opinion leader empowered patients’ relationship with their medical professionals, their experiences and beliefs about technologies, and how they see the future. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Describe examples of groundbreaking studies combining artificial narrowing intelligence with human cognition in the healthcare sector, highlighting their success in achieving better results than either alone. [/INST] The question about A.I. is never technology vs humans. GM Garry Kasparov introduced the concept of advanced chess, also known as cyborg or centaur chess. He wanted to bring together human and computer skills to achieve the following results: - increasing the level of play to heights never before seen in chess; - producing blunder-free games with the qualities and the beauty of both perfect tactical play and highly meaningful strategic plans; - offering the public an overview of the mental processes of strong human chess players and powerful chess computers, and the combination of their forces. The most exciting medical studies that used machine or deep learning did not conclude that algorithms are better than physicians at doing a specific task but those that showed how the combination of computational and human cognition leads to the best results.  My favorite studies in this are the ones with detecting breast cancer on slides and diabetic retinopathy on retinal images. Excellent results underscoring the notion that artificial narrow intelligence will work with medical professionals and vice versa for the best results.  Have you seen other similar studies concluding the same? Photo source:  Kasparov.com #digitalhealth   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #TMFchessjourney

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Describe a digital health innovation that showcases the potential of technology combined with human expertise to transform patient outcomes and highlight the importance of guiding patients through digital health technologies. [/INST] Digital health is a cultural transformation. That’s a key message I regularly address in my keynotes and also a basis of The Medical Futurist Institute’s research on the paradigm shift currently taking place in healthcare. Let me demonstrate it through an example.  Brennan Spiegel, MD, MSHS  and the VR clinical research team at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center have been doing a tremendous job assessing the health benefits of virtual reality. They have been experimenting with the technology for several years and found a significant drop in pain scores in case of VR therapies. What strikes me in their story is that the immersive,  multi-sensory environments had a more significant impact on patients when medical professionals participated in the therapy as a guide, introducing the technology gradually and coaching the patient along the session. VR is an area of endless possibilities, but it can demonstrate it’s real effect when it’s combined with the human touch, medical professionals taking up the role of guiding their patients through digital health technologies. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #speaker   #keynote   #speakerlife

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:As a chess player approaching 1500 ELO, I reflect on the parallels between mastering the game and the complex challenges of medicine, ultimately arguing that incorporating artificial narrow intelligence into daily medical practice is crucial for optimizing therapy and monitoring. [/INST] So I've been progresing in chess studying openings and exercising 2-3 hours every day. I'm around 1400 ELO on  chess.com  (an increase of 600 points since November). I learn so much about how A.I. will be used in medicine on the way. Rudolf Spielmann said that in chess, ""Play the opening like a book, the middle game like a magician, and the endgame like a machine.” There is a huge overlap with how we practice medicine.  The opening is obtaining data and information about patients. It should be done like reading a book. Seamless and by the rules. The middle game is the hard part: making a diagnosis. It is even currently being done like magicians do their job. A lot of people don't understand it but it's fascinating, hard and creative.  The endgame is the therapy and monitoring part which should work like a machine: automated following guidelines. This is only possible by implementing artificial narrow intelligence into the daily work of medical professionals. This is why it's so important to understand the basics of A.I. On the photo, I discuss an opening issue with a potential GM. ☺ #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #TMFchessjourney

The Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America describes that a peak flow meter is a handheld device that measures how well air moves out of your lungs. It can measure how narrow your airways are hours, even days, before you have any asthma symptoms. By taking your asthma medicine when your peak flow meter indicates changes – before you notice symptoms – you may be able to avoid a serious asthma episode. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What potential advancements in medicine and healthcare do you think reinforcement learning, as seen in the AlphaGo algorithm, could bring, and how might it alter the balance between human expertise and computational analysis in medical decision-making? [/INST] On my A.I. journey, I just had a workshop with a developer who works with deep and machine learning algorithms. I had a hundred questions and he helped me understand the details of not just these methods but also their implications for medicine and healthcare.  What stroke me the most was what I learnt about reinforcement learning. AlphaGo that beat the world's best GO player (Lee Sedol, on the photo) also used that. It means you describe rules and then let the algorithm get outputs. Then you retrospectively tell the algorithm which output was fine and it creates its own rules for reaching those outputs. Do you know what it means?  It means it's not bound the cognitive limitation of people. Physicians have been accusing me that I want to take away their "art of practicing medicine". I now go further than that. The era of medicine being an art will just begin when reinforcement learning tackles medical tasks. Can you imagine what new ways we will learn about finding cures, treatments and managing conditions? Ways we have never thought of. Just like how AlphaGo made moves nobody made before for thousands of years. What do you think? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #TMFchessjourney

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Can you explain the key difference between the terms "health IT" and "digital health", and why introducing the "Gary-rule" is essential in healthcare settings? [/INST] The special issue of The Journal of Clinical and Translational Research just came out. Do you know the difference between health IT and digital health? A lot of people and even large organizations don't. That's why I introduced the Gary-rule in it. Here it is. If a technological issue comes up in a healthcare setting such as the antivirus software becomes outdated or the electronic medical record system stopped working, and we have to call Gary, the IT guy, as he is alone capable of solving it whatever methods he uses, it’s an IT issue. If Gary is not enough to address the problem because more stakeholders of healthcare must get involved, (e.g., letting patients bring the data of their trackers into the medical practice and merge that with electronic medical records, or allowing physicians to do remote consultations on a regular basis), it’s digital health. The paper is in open access:  https://lnkd.in/g2UvetW #healthcare   #medicine   #digitalhealth   #healthIT   #future

[/INST] As even organizations like the WHO have been mixing up health IT and digital health, I published an editorial in the Journal of Clinical and Translational Research and introduced the Gary rule to clear up this misconception.  If a technological issue comes up in a healthcare setting such as the anti-virus software becomes outdated and we have to call Gary, the IT guy, as he is alone capable of solving it what-ever methods he uses, it’s an IT issue. If Gary is not enough to solve the issue because more stakeholders of healthcare must get involved, (e.g. letting patients bring the data of their trackers into the practice and merging that with electronic medical records), it’s digital health.  https://lnkd.in/g2UvetW

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Create a narrative about a person's increasingly disillusioned relationship with food, technology, and traditional dining experiences in the face of personalized, health-oriented eating recommendations. [/INST] I ordered steak. The menu item blinked in red twice in my digital lens but I didn’t care. I was very hungry and I love meat. Since it became possible to merge our genomic data with health records in the cloud synchronized with each and every digital device, choosing food has turned into a stressful activity. They wanted to tell me what and when to eat and it has made me crazy. They knew better what me and especially my body needed. My grandfather told me that back in the day nobody knew what the hell you were eating. You just went to a restaurant, ordered and finished your meal. Simple as that. I know they died from a lot of diseases without any foreseeable signs but still. That freedom of choice is special. I don’t even understand why we bother to eat at all today. Just choose whatever is tailored to me and bring it in a powder or something. It’s not worth the effort when it’s so expensive to eat less healthy foods or choose what is out of my metabolic bounds. Sometimes I wish I were in the old ages with infections, sudden deaths, and short lifespans. But man, going out to eat whatever you want must have been a hell of an experience. I get back to my steak, which is obviously artificial but might taste like those dishes my grandfather talked about.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Distinctiate between healthcare IT issues, which can be resolved by IT staff alone, and digital health issues that require collaboration between IT and healthcare professionals. [/INST] As even organizations like the WHO have been mixing up health IT and digital health, I published an editorial in the Journal of Clinical and Translational Research and introduced the Gary rule to clear up this misconception.  If a technological issue comes up in a healthcare setting such as the anti-virus software becomes outdated and we have to call Gary, the IT guy, as he is alone capable of solving it what-ever methods he uses, it’s an IT issue.  If Gary is not enough to solve the issue because more stakeholders of healthcare must get involved, (e.g. letting patients bring the data of their trackers into the practice and merging that with electronic medical records), it’s digital health.  http://bit.ly/2CEg4UN #ai   #technology   #health   #healthIT   #digitalhealth   #research

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What lessons did you learn from reading Michelle McMullin/Katherine Eban's 'Bad Blood: Secrets and Lies in a Silicon Valley Startup' about the ethics of digital health innovation? [/INST] I followed the Theranos story from the beginning. I wrote about them in 2015 saying that they would decide the fate of medical innovation for some time. If they fail because they lied about their technology, it will doom investors' trust for long. If they succeed, they will rewrite the rule of healthcare. Still, Bad Blood turned out to be one of (if not) the best non-fiction books I've ever read.  Literally, you can't put this book down. It's like Stephen King wrote about digital health. A very dark story that works as a cautionary tale for all of us.  Some things that marked this experience: 1) in digital health you are worth nothing without evidence-based background, 2) if something seems too good to be true, be vigilant, and 3) human decency must remain at the core of what represents us even when we are about to make a huge contribution to healthcare. If you read it, what did you learn? #theranos   #badblood   #book   #reading   #healthcare   #digitalhealth

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Describe a positive experience with a chatbot that provided personalized care and guidance for a mysterious illness, highlighting the benefits of virtual primary care in modern healthcare. [/INST] I woke up in the morning with a sore throat. I immediately turned to my voice assistant to ask for help. She asked me to take a picture of my throat with a phone and she guided me to make sure I get a photo good enough for analysis. I snapped the picture, uploaded it to her cloud and she responded in a second: "You have a sore throat and let's make sure it will go away as smoothly as possible."  She told me what to have for breakfast, what kind of tea to make and what over-the-counter drug to start with. She also told me she would monitor my vital signs through my skin patch and will let me know if I need antibiotics. I asked her how much time it would take to get better and whether I can work today. She responded with empathy and encouragement sharing the conclusions of analyzing millions of patient journeys with the same issue: "We will take care of it together, don't worry. You are in good hands." After a few days of guidance and suggestions, she made me get better sooner than expected. At not one point I felt alone with my problems. This is primary care in the 2020s and I love chatbots. Well, I wouldn't have enough money to see real a doctor anyway. #chatbot   #ai   #technology   #health   #healthcare

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Writing about your first exposure to racism through an iconic moment in sports history and its impact on your personal perspective and relationship with your grandfather. [/INST] I remember watching Hank Aaron break Babe Ruth's home run record on television with my grandfather when I was four years old. It was my first realization of racism as my grandpa explained that Aaron was the best athlete alive, in his opinion, but that he wasn't treated as such by many because he was black. It made no sense to me, a child who was growing up in rural, predominantly white Minnesota but I knew what Aaron had done was a very big deal, by my grandfather's reaction. Bigger than being the best baseball player alive. I am grateful to Henry Louis Aaron for combating racism and changing hearts and minds with his talent and grateful to my grandfather for having a conversation with me that too many  parents or grandparents would likely avoid having with a four year old.  #perseverance   #champion

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Write a reflective and emotional 250-300 word essay describing the impact of a historical tragedy on a nation, contrasting its unification and sense of community with the current state of division and its effects on empathy and national unity. [/INST] I will never forget September 11, 2001. I won't forget the shock of watching two airplanes fly into the world trade center and the horror of those towers tumbling to the ground, knowing there were precious lives being lost, 2977 to be exact and thousands more injured. I also won't forget how united we felt as a nation as I saw American flags on cars, homes and businesses. The way we looked at one another even though we may have been strangers, and showed shared grief in a glance. We felt sorrow and fear together and we were united in fiercely defending our nation, our freedom, from anyone who dare attack it.  I have thought a great deal about that today and how divided we are now. I wonder what the date will be that we will memorialize in future years as the final day an American died of Covid 19. I wish we were attacking this adversary as a united front and coming together rather than it pulling us apart. Where is our empathy for those among us who are physically at risk, where is our sense of duty to protect our neighbor and other members of our community? Where is our ability to understand there is much we still don't know and not knowing is not dependent on our party affiliation. I will never forget what we lost on 9/11 or who we are capable of being.   #america   #compassion

Bring a plate of cookies or bowl of fruit to a neighbor. Start an office or neighborhood coat drive and donate winter coats to a local homeless shelter. Volunteer to listen to kids read at a local school. Let someone go ahead of you in line, just because. Put treats out for neighbors who walk their dogs. Explore a part of town you typically don't visit to shop, go to a play or musical event. Share your talent by volunteering some time to teaching even one person how to play an instrument, paint, draw, sing or act. Do handyman/woman jobs for a neighbor. Mow or take a lawn or shovel a walk for someone who needs help doing it. Organize a trash pickup day at a local park, beach, creek side... Give someone a compliment each day. Start a cooking club and take turns hosting dinner for friends. Invite a guest. Look at the checkout clerk when they say "hello" and ask you how your day is going. Ask them how their day is going too. Listen to their answer and be present.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Envisioning and replicating community-run, regional healthcare models inspired by the Hospices De Beaune in France, exploring the potential for entrepreneurial and grassroots solutions to provide compassionate care to all, regardless of socioeconomic status, in the United States. [/INST] It was a pleasure visiting the Hospices De Beaune in the Burgundy region of France today.  The story of Chancellor Nicolas Rolin who in 1443 built a beautiful place to care for the poor and sick at no charge really struck me.  He didn't cut corners and great thought went into creating a beautiful, compassionate environment for healing.  Wealthier patients did pay a small fee and had more private accommodations. Many also freely donated. The church and King Louis also provided funds and nuns cared for the sick. Those funds insured that everyone received care. Nuns even made fresh bread every morning to give to the townspeople who were suffering after the hundred year war. Wine from grapes in the vineyard were sold to fund the hospital.  To this day it is a symbol of great pride and compassion in the region.   Care and compassion to those who are suffering in a community makes the entire community stronger and more peaceful. People who show up and support one another thrive.  What would happen if in America there were smaller, regional models of care like this? Could communities create and find ways to fund care for everyone rich or poor?  Would someone be willing to manage it without receiving a seven figure salary?   #entrepeneurship   #healthcare   #business   #community 
 
 
 …see more </s>
