<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Can our willingness to consume "free" products and services without paying for them lead to a culture of exploitation, where personal data is commodified and users are subjected to unwanted advertising, and if so, what alternatives or changes need to be made to protect consumers' interests? [/INST] Is "free" really free when it comes to social media platforms or other web or app based consumer products? My answer is a resounding "no" but I am not sure everyone sees it that way.  When creating alska and coming up with a pricing structure we were met with skepticism when saying we would charge customers a monthly fee of $8.99.  Some said "Consumers won't pay when there are so many free products."  Many said we should make it free to the consumer and generate revenue by selling data or advertising.  I thought it would be important for users to know that their information is protected and they wouldn't be inundated by advertisements for products or other services that may or may not be reputable.  Even when I look at competitors who claim to offer a solution to caregivers, I quickly see that they are mining data right from the initial attempt to register an account.  This turns me off immediately and I assume my customers would have the same reaction but, maybe not. Facebook still states on their registration page "it's free and always will be."  There are rumors that may change, what do you think? Would you rather pay for an application with cash or are you willing to roll the dice with your personal information and be advertised to?

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Analyze how current market trends, investor sentiment, and the Federal Reserve's policies interact in the context of soaring stock prices compared to a supposedly floundering economy. [/INST] From the Wall Street Journal:  "The Dow Jones Industrial Average staged its best two-week performance since the 1930s, a dramatic rebound that has left many investors with a confounding reality: soaring share prices and a floundering economy." One can think of three possible explanations for this dispersion:   Markets are a lot more forward-looking and are comfortable looking through what many believe is a temporary and reversible downturn in the economy;   Markets are over-optimistic, conditioned by years of great success for "buy-the-dip" strategies; and   Actual and expected support by the Federal Reserve has again decoupled markets from economic and corporate fundamentals. Depending on who you ask, you are likely to get a different ranking of the three ... with one quite interesting tendency: The closer the investors are to the real economy, the more cautious they are about the sustainability of the rally (e.g., what the Journal reported about Warren Buffett's approach this time around and compared to the 2008/09 crisis, and the remarks by Mark Cuban). #markets   #investing   #bonds   #economy   #volatility   #equities   #stocks   #interestrates   #federalreserve   #selloff   #investmentmanagement   #investors   #Fed   #wsj

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:How can sympathetically reengaging with job-struggling contacts make a impactful difference in their lives and career prospects? [/INST] 'Tis the season to catch up with people you haven't seen or spoken to for awhile, and chances are someone in your network is out of work.  The best present you can give them this year isn't a gift card ... or your pity. Give them the gift of your time (and connections) instead. 1. Acknowledge how hard their situation is. Sugar coating doesn't help; your sympathy will. Try not to be afraid of their sorrow or anger, and by all means don't treat their unemployment as if it's contagious. 2. Offer to get together after the holidays. Treat them to a lunch or cup of coffee; when you're worried about money, this goes a long way. And don't talk exclusively about their job search. Have a real, human conversation. Make them laugh, if possible. 3. Ask them specifically what they're looking for and identify quality contacts in your network for introductions. Stay on the lookout for job openings, as well as new contacts who might offer the next step in the process. 4. Stay in touch. There's nothing lonelier than looking for a job.   5. Ask: "How can I help?" and then deliver. Ghosting is an exceptionally hurtful thing to do to a job seeker.

[/INST] What does it actually mean to be grateful, the most overused (and possibly least understood) word of the holiday season? *Gratitude isn’t about mouthing platitudes; it’s about a heightened awareness of what we experience, down to a comfortable office chair or a warm sip of coffee.  When we stop taking things for granted, we immediately widen our capacity for patience and creativity.  And yet, being grateful is not the same as being passive. We can be thankful for what we have while still advocating for more justice and equality in the workplace. *Telling people (such as your employees or colleagues) to be "thankful for what they have" produces the exact opposite effect.  *It’s impossible to experience gratitude when we believe we’re solely responsible for where we are in our careers. Gratitude and entitlement are always mutually exclusive.  What have you learned about gratitude in the workplace?

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:How can acknowledging and expressing gratitude instead of apology improve relationships in the workplace and everyday interactions? [/INST] When do you say "I'm sorry?" For many of us, "I'm sorry" is our meaningless default response when we've inconvenienced a colleague. The better response is to recognize what they did for us, and say  "Thank you" instead.  Try "Thanks for your flexibility" instead of "I'm sorry I'm late because (insert lame excuse here)." Try "Thank you for your patience" instead of "I'm sorry I missed that deadline (more flimsy excuses here)." A good followup is stating how you'll make sure that specific behavior doesn't happen again. This change in vocabulary does something powerful: it shifts the focus away from you and toward the person who had to accommodate you. Of course, if a situation warrants a genuine apology, saying "I'm sorry" is only the first step toward reconciliation, not the end point.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the essential points that a company should immediately address in its crisis communications statement following a major scandal or data breach? [/INST] Dead silence is never an appropriate response in the wake of a crisis. Never. Ever.  When the scandal broke about Cambridge Analytica and the massive misuse of personal information on Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg explained to the New York Times that he needed time to figure out what to say.   Bunk. These are the points Facebook could have addressed within 30 minutes of the news: 1. We are sorry for the harm we caused our followers. 2. We are figuring out how we can make amends. 3. We are working on a plan to make sure this never happens again. 3. We will have an update for you on (date). Rinse and repeat every time more information is available to be released to the public and to shareholders. Even if you're not Facebook, all companies need a template for a crisis communications statement. That allows for quick messages to be pushed out in an hour or less.  Four days is an eternity in the age of social media. And when a company fails to fill the void following a crisis of this scale, we will fill it for them. And in this case, it's a rallying cry to #deleteFacebook.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Explore the transformative power of "yes and" vs. "no but" in navigating high-stakes conversations, and discuss how this simple linguistic shift can improve communication, build trust, and foster a more collaborative approach to conflict resolution. [/INST] Two of my favorite words -- "Yes and" -- are indispensable during negotiations or tense conversations. "No but" often becomes our default phrase when the stakes are high. We're afraid to use "yes" in these situations because we mistakenly think it's synonymous with agreement.  "Yes" means: "I hear you. I understand what you're saying."  "And" means: "Now I will share my take on the situation." Replacing "No but" with "Yes and" isn't a magic wand. But this simple substitution improves the chances of breaking up a conversational logjam. When we feel acknowledged, we're less defensive and more open to listening to other points of view. At the very least, the door to moving forward remains ajar instead of closed.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What if companies had the opportunity to transform their business foundations from the ground up, combining interior design with existential problem-solving, rather than just refurbishing their digital storefronts? [/INST] A lot of companies these days are essentially like buildings constructed in the wrong place, with the wrong foundations. We think that interior design will stop people from noticing. We'd rather have chats about new sofas and new wallpaper, than face the idea we've got existential problems that need deep rethinking. Department stores simply do not need to exist, banks need to accept it's customer experience, not vaults that matter. Car companies need to accept car dealerships are increasingly unhelpful. TV companies need to rethink the rules and opportunities of entertainment.  People think of digital transformation as the refurbishment business. People think transformation is like "home decor" shows where you know a month after the camera crew leaves the hacks, the workarounds, the sprayed on silver, have worn off and reality hits you. It was exciting, it looked better, people seemed happy but the issues remain.  Digital transformation needs to move from refurbishment to the construction industry. A way to build the construction you should have, in the place you should have, and to then plan the migration between the two.   It's not cheap, it's not fast, it's not easy, but for some companies it's essential Often a startups only advantage, is that it starts from nothing

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:The democratization of advertising has reordered the industry's landscape, fundamentally changing how brands acquire and advertise with others. [/INST] The big story of Advertising since 2010 isn't that things went online, it's that Advertising became democratized.  In 2005 -  you needed a media buyer, a media planner, a creative shop and there were perhaps 100,000 advertisers, spending an average of $1m. The more you spent, the better the rates. In 2020- there are perhaps 12 million advertisers, spending an average of $40,000.  To advertise you need a credit card and the prices are the same for everyone. The advertising ecosystem still exists because the top 100,000 spenders still behave like the used to, and the 12,900,000 new Advertisers were incremental. The big questions will be: What happens when the 5,000th biggest advertiser acquires a brand that's tripled in size in a year, spent the same on media as them, and employs 1/50th of the people in Marketing. What happens a $100m advertiser's CFO hears at a conference that a $5bn brand has no agencies.  The best question remains "what would your company look like if you set it up today" & the scary question is you'd create nothing like any large agency.  You'd have 100 times fewer but better people, generalists and specialists, no more than 5 offices in the world, you'd bring commerce and content and advertising and customer experience together.  It would be easy.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Evaluate the implications of $2 trillion spent on digital transformation without a corresponding shift in daily life experiences. [/INST] I went pretty punchy with this piece for the National. These may be totally unprecedented times, but that doesn't mean they were totally unpredictable. Common wisdom dictates that large companies need to act small, we need to disrupt or die and that radical business transformation is essential to not only survival, but untold riches. We face three broad options, depending on the degree to which you've noticed new possibilities. 1) Embrace the new- Enjoy the new possibilities that come from removed constraints. Choose to embrace them, become excited about what they mean and change elements of your life around them. 2) Mitigate. Tried to minimize changes, and fit a slightly new life into the same shaped container of the past, with required adaptation. 3) Resist.  if you've struggled to change, constantly notice the new constraints, ponder what you miss about the old world, and routinely dismiss what's possible. There is a LOT of great chat now about "rethinking work" and new ways to brainstorm remotely or explore ideas collaboratively.  I can help but think it's easier than that. 1) Companies need to use meetings the right way. Is it to make decisions, to get buy in, to sell or to create a feeling of togetherness.  Choose the attendees, format, preparation and time for it based around that. 2) Do the things that matter most, say no to 80% of things. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What innovative business models could be explored for the modern book industry, moving beyond the traditional limited offerings and incorporating emerging digital technologies to enhance reader engagement and experiences? [/INST] There could be a lot more imagination in how books are sold.  -You could pay more for one with a celebrity reading it.  -You could pay more to access podcast series that expands on the book and ensures it's up to date. -You could pay more for an abridged version. -You could pay to rent a digital copy for a short time. -You could pay more to access an online forum where people discuss the book -You could buy the first chapter of the book for $1 and see if you like it, before paying more to unlock each chapter. -You could pay to get a physical copy and the audiobook -You could pay more for an online training course based on the book, with live sessions, groupwork, and mentorship In fact the idea of books as complete items that don't link out to any media, that are not updated for years, on which you can readily see how others think, it's a remarkably outdated idea.  If we consider the role of the book is not based around the physicality of the book, but the need to be inspired, to learn, to change how you think, books become very different commercial propositions.  I may try an explore these false limitations in my next book.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What if I were to replace a "self-driving car" with the inner workings of a business, and explore how the supposed benefits of objective, data-driven processes often come at the cost of explaining and replicating human intuition and creativity? [/INST] The very best "self-driving car" is still less capable and safe that some of the worst ever human drivers.  I think about this a lot. If you were to ask someone driving what they were doing, they wouldn't really know. They'd be driving with a mixture of data, feelings, and memory. They'd sense the person crossing the road will take longer because of their demeanor, that a branch could flt on the road because it's windy, but they'd not be able to explain why they feel that way.  Self-driving cars use about 40Gbits per second, they learn from the past, they use incredibly advanced technology that we should be impressed by. We know precisely how they work. But a self-driving car can't tell the difference between a  rock and a packet of crisps on the highway. Some see badly in the sun. They struggle with unmapped roads and with the snow for example.  This feels for me how modern businesses are run. We love processes that seem objective, repeatable, we demand they use vast amounts of data, we don't mind that all their learning comes from that past. We care more than the process is understandable and the same & robust than the outcomes.  Meanwhile the human guided by feelings, predictions, intuitions, bias,  emotion, does a far better job, but in a way that can't be explained

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Describe a world where the widespread adoption of digital technology in schools led to a revolution in education, transforming the core curriculum to align with the needs of the 21st century with reduced emphasis on outdated subjects. [/INST] I remember being in Primary school in 1987 when we got the Schools first Computer, it was proudly placed in a Classroom and people line up to be allowed to use it.   By 1990 we had one computer in every classroom. By 1993, now in Secondary school, we had a special computer room, where all computers were placed together, we had an IT teacher too to "own" IT. By 1997 some kids were getting computers at home, by 2005 some kids had laptops, around 2018 is was expected that kids in many schools used their own Laptops or Tablets to be the hub of all the work they do. This best explains how Digital Transformation occurs, we add a little, then we add more, then we have a center that owns transformation, and then it disbands and it's done everywhere. Yet today, kids still learn languages, maths, english literature, History, with a bit of coding added on. If we assume that Schooling is to prepare kids for life, we'd teach them financial literacy, how to build relationships, how to consume media, how to look after their mental health. Digital should change what you do.  You should rethink what you do from the core and for the future. Not augment the old. But all we ever do is add it on & most of us are still in the Computer room phase.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What does the "New Dark Age" of James Bridle's concept represent in our hyper-connected world, and how do we reclaim our ability to think critically in the face of technological advancements? [/INST] I think about this quote all the time, "We find ourselves today connected to vast repositories of knowledge and yet we have not learned to think. In fact, the opposite is true: that which was intended to enlighten the world in practice darkens it. The abundance of information and the plurality of worldviews now accessible to us through the internet are not producing a coherent consensus reality, but one riven by fundamentalist insistence on simplistic narratives, conspiracy theories, and post-factual politics.  It is on this contradiction that the idea of a new dark age turns: an age in which the value we have placed upon knowledge is destroyed by the abundance of that profitable commodity, and in which we look about ourselves in search of new ways to understand the world" James Bridle - from "New Dark Age: Technology and the End of the Future"  2018  I wish more people were working on a plan ahead.

It's often progress that doesn't matter,  but that has a hardness, specificity, and objectivity to it.  Get comfortable with vague feelings of progress towards something meaningful. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What is the true measure of digital transformation excellence, and how can legacy companies overcome the entrenched mindset that holds them back from truly innovating and competing with modern startups? [/INST] Over the last 10 years around $15 Trillion has been spent on Digital Transformation, and yet there are (perhaps) zero case studies of real success. Sure, websites have got prettier, companies have got better EPOS systems, better inventory management, more "data", but have we "Transformed" or  improved. Almost all "Transformation" is simply keeping up with others, maintaining systems or making small incremental improvements. A key part of the issue is that the past holds us back, old systems form the bedrock of most companies, and nobody dare change a foundation that everybody understands "that" it works, but nobody understands "how" it works.  Senior personnel in IT know that their value comes from knowing how to maintain what they have, from understanding where the skeletons are, from knowing old code, why would they become less valuable building something new?  Legacy companies are basically a world of brick buildings, limited by the physics of bricks, built by bricklayers.  Modern startups are engineers who build from steel and glass. It's a whole new world. Legacy companies won't get there without changing everything they do, the skills they have, and start building new, not seeking to renovate or decorate the old. When they get this, exciting things will happen fast.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:Can online retail be transformed into an enjoyable and thrilling experience to match its convenience, making customers look forward to buying instead of just tolerating the process? [/INST] Online shopping is basically really good when you know specifically what you want.  If you want the Samsung UE32T4307,  or the Beko MGI25332BG - you're two clicks away from a wonderful product at the best price. But the reality is that 99% of stuff we buy isn't like that. Many items don't have product names, many items we need a little  help (and reassurance) in selection, and most items we buy based on discovery and browsing ( Shopping vs Buying )  I maintain that Amazon is the best logistics company the world has ever seen and one of the worst retailers. By stores around the world emulating their faults, we've ended up with awful online retail everywhere. If we were rather unambitious we would make selection easier, we'd craft a more premium experience, we'd make things simpler, we'd have more imaginative ways to filter products.  But the real challenge and opportunity is how do we make buying fun, how do we make it something people would choose to spend time doing. The world of VC is Inherently: -Risk-averse it finds well-proven business models, often from years ago ( reoccurring revenue, monthly boxes, ad and data supported, direct to consumer etc etc) as a basis for investment. -Backwards looking, as valuations can only be based on multiples of business models with ample historical data to support it -Insular as VC firms look to each other for inspiration, they decide together that 2018 will be the year AI, Voice, or Crypto are the companies to favor, in 2020 it will be about wellness, remote access. They make decisions based on a fear of missing out, not a passion for what can be done.  -Tech centric, it’s based on the tech du jour, and ignores any aspect of what consumers would love, or what problems we’ve love solved, or what new possibilities there are to create consumer delight VC has killed real innovation, Silicon Valley is the best place to make money from well-executed poor identikit ideas.  Why can’t we have true innovation, people who really want to make things that improve our lives? Why can’t we solve problems in the world?

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the long-term implications and potential drawbacks of the shift towards remote work, and how might this paradigm shift change the nature of work and companies? [/INST] I think we are lying to ourselves. I keep seeing pieces saying "this forced experiment shows working from home works" and that "office demand will collapse" & "cities will die"  A couple of things hit me. 1) It is working in the sense that we have hung on, battled through a crisis, we've have largely kept our jobs, & kept the lights on. This is a situation we are forced into, not one we have chosen as a preference. Yes, we've spent less money, energy & time on commuting, but depression has skyrocketed, anxiety is rife, our mental health has suffered, we feel more alone & we drink more.Long term success is more than survival 2) Did anyone think that working from home was not possible before?  We've had fast broadband/laptops for 13 years, we knew we could work like this, we largely made an informed decision not to. 3) Clearly the future of work is not binary It's working from home, working near home, working near a satellite office and HQ, working from planes, conferences, etc  It should involve more company away days, less time commuting, but it's likely most companies will need large spaces to congregate & employees to rush to the office with short notice sometimes. 4)Many things in life are inefficient, business lunches, flying to shake a hand, that's why they mean a lot.

[/INST] Lots of people have had a pretty transformative vacation at some point. The last Saturday evening, a balmy evening walk on a beach or around a harbor. A week away from the office and email as our master, our phone as handcuffs, blinkers off. Three days later and the memories have faded, the promises we made to ourselves seem like a distant memory, our hopes and perspective seem worn down by reality and an alarm clock. Even at the airport our pulses raced as we track down bags and experience the chill of normal/   But this time it’s different. Everyone will have been through the same feelings. Everyone . You won’t be alone in your new found perspective, you can be part of a cohort of people with the same aspirations, the same need for balance, to get things done, to focus on what matters, to be proud of what you can build and who want to rebel against politics, process, risk aversion and what grinds us all down. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What is the consequences of standardizing and commodifying the most vital part of a company, treating talent as a form of capital to be managed and controlled? [/INST] The worst thing we ever did in corporate America was to take the most vital part of any company - the people powering it - and label it so dismissively as “human resources.”  We reduced talent to a simple asset: one to be standardized, controlled, commoditized, and managed like any other form of capital. We created a department whose sole purpose is to extract value and enforce compliance, and put them in charge of an ecosystem built around formalized processes, sameness, common practices, and conformity.  The result is the institutionalized mediocrity plaguing many legacy companies today. A pandemic that will only become more problematic as we advance into the post-digital age: a world of agile, talent-focused companies that are set up to disrupt, excel and grow. <s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are some essential strategies to craft effective and persuasive requests for help when citing a person's time, attention, or resources as a limiting factor? [/INST] Little tip.  It is safe to assume that people really like helping other people.  Generally speaking, those people with the most influence / money / authority to help, have some of the greatest demands on their time & attention.  So when asking for help, try to do three things. 1) Make it as easy as possible to help them. Don't reduce the scope of help needed, but reduce the mental effort required form the other person.  2) Be specific and honest about the help you need.  These are the big two. The 3rd is a bonus. 3) Showing you've been thoughtful and empathetic is wonderful. It's not an ego play, but it shows the person that you are thoughtful, but also shows you've put effort it, that you've not just send the same thing to 100 random people.

<s>[INST] Generate a LinkedIn Post for:What are the key qualities and work arrangements needed to unlock the full potential of innovative and adaptable teams in the modern workforce? [/INST] It's likely that the very best people and the precise type of people you need most, are the hardest people to work with. And Vice Versa. As younger people enter the workforce, this is only going to become more apparent.  Pretty much all notions of work come from the command and control structure of armed forces centuries ago, tweaked for the needs of industrialists in factories 200 years ago. They needed people to be cogs in a machine, to be easily replaced, to be specialists, to be opinionless. Companies need to make the most of people, not the same of people. This means flexible working hours, working from home, embracing passions and side projects. It means people with width, and oddness, who can do 8 different things and need to.  We need to accept that literally the only thing that matters is outputs, not process or location, or presenteeism, or even how hard you worked. I'm not saying you need to employ hard people, far from it, I'm saying working with and around the best people will be hard.

Predicting the general path of the future is pretty easy, it's about empathy. I think we kid ourselves it's harder than it is.
